text:
Great recipe, with ONE exception: I initially followed the directions to whisk the flour/eggs then add the wet ingredients, but this left me with VERY lumpy unusable batter. Doing the reverse - mixing the eggs & wet stuff then sifting in the flour - worked way better.

text:
BRILLIANT BASIC CREPES.
This is a scrumptious recipe for thin, delicious German style pancakes. I'm a professional musician and recording artist, and I often find myself in the kitchens of recording studios, trying to make something edible from the staple ingredients studios keep in their kitchens. Well, this recipe is it!!! Everyone has milk, eggs, salt, butter, and flour in their kitchen, and these babies whip up like a charm! Even the batter will keep in the fridge for a few days. Personally, I like to throw in about a third cup of granulated sugar and a quarter cup of powdered sugar to make them sweet and a little crispy around the edges. Just be sure to put a fresh dab of butter in the pan before pouring the batter each time. I've tried countless pancake/crepe recipes, and nothing really impressed me until this one. I recommend it most enthusiastically!

Christine Anderson

I had a hard time wrapping my brain around the flour + eggs, then other ingredients....so I just did what I always do....wet stuff blended, then dry stuff added to it. They have turned out great every time I have made them. A touch of sugar and vanilla makes great sweet crepes...some pepper and herbs make great veggie crepes. BOTH are great for breakfast! I almost always double or triple this recipe, and it keeps well in the fridge.

text:
super recipe! I live in Europe and got tired of buying the already prepared just add water mixes so I tried this one out! REALLY REALLY easy!
I find a good trick if using a non stick pan is to shake it back and forth with the handle now and then- when the crepe begins to slip back and forth it is done on the primary side so you flip and really quickly do the other side or it gets rubbery.

text:
Delicious!    TIPS FOR SMOOTH, LUMP-FREE BATTER (LEARNED AT SCHOOL :)  1) Add flour to GLASS bowl.  Add salt.  Mix. Make a well in the centre. 2)  Use ONE measuring jug and add/measure the milk & water together!  Add BEATEN egg to this and give it a stir. 3)  Using a WHISK, slowly incorporate the wet ingredients (best if at ROOM TEMP) a little at a time, stirring in small circular movements (your wrist will hurt a little :) 4) Continue adding wet ingredients,  stirring/whisking with whisk, until all the flour is incorporated.   5)  Add melted, room temp butter and stir in.  PERFECTLY SMOOTH. 6)  Cover with plastic wrap and leave for +- 20mins (not essential, but preferable).  Good Luck :)

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic, very tasty, very easy crepe recipe!

After many trial runs, I've found a few tweaks to make them even easier and yummier. Add a 1/3 cup of sugar to give the crepes extra sweetness. Mix all the dry ingredients (flour, sugar, salt) together before whisking in the eggs. After adding the eggs, your mixture should be a thick, sticky clump that will probably get trapped between the wires of your whisk. Now pour the melted butter over this clumpy mixture and stir to form a dough-like consistency. Doing this allows you to smooth out your batter and get rid of any lumps. At this point, add a 1/2 tsp. of vanilla extract for flavor and stir into the dough. Instead of milk, try using half and half or even heavy cream for a richer flavor and slightly thicker crepe. Whatever you choose, be sure to add it to the mixture a splash at a time and stir completely before adding more to ensure that your ingredients will be evenly distributed. The same care should be taken when mixing in the water. I do not recommend altering the ratio of water to milk (or cream), as the crepes tend not to cook as nicely (they become either too puffy or too thin and brittle). The perfectionists out there (I among them... saying it loud and proud!), should remove 1/2 tsp. from the 1/2 cup of water in the recipe to account for the added vanilla extract, though failing to do so does not seem to impact the finished product.

text:
I've made this recipe twice.  First time, I took the advice from another member that said to beat the eggs with the milk and water first. THEN add the flour.  Turned out great.  This time I decided to follow the recipe which is beating the eggs and flour first.  HUGE MISTAKE!  It was like a big glob of goo then did not blend.  Instead it was a watery, chunky mess.  I re-made this the way I did the first time and VOILA!  Perfect.  Remember:  Beat all the wet, then mix in the dry.  :)

text:
Quick and Easy, especially when you have 2 pans going at once!  I just spray a 6 in pan with PAM and when it turns dark brown from the heat I add the very scant 1/4 cup of batter.  I added a tbsp. of sugar and a tsp. of vanilla as I was making dessert crepes. I always make a lot and freeze the extras between layers of waxed paper.   
 My mother's favorite (I make her about 20 of them for her every Mother's day so she has a special breakfast for weeks) is when I make a cream cheese filling (block of softened cream cheese, tsp of lemon juice, lemon zest, 1/2 cup of sour cream, 1-2 cups of cool whip, blended) with sliced fresh strawberries that I have coated with sugar to form a syrup. I have also have served chocolate pecan crepes (melted dark chocolate chips with chopped pecans). This makes a very fancy dessert when you offer them both as choices. I actually loved dipping the strawberry crepes into the chocolate!

text:
When I told my husband I was going to make crepes for breakfast, his initial response was "How? We don't have a crepe maker"... as it turns out, you don't need one!!! Amazingly easy and fast meal to make! The only changes I made was I used whole wheat flour as we don't have white in the house, and I added a packet of stevia as I was making them with strawberries and carob chips. All I have to say is YUM!!! I think this will be a staple for years to come! I also used both a frying pan to start and a flat grill to finish. I've never been able to flip things in one piece, so it was just a matter of flipping the pan over and letting gravity do the work- and it made things super fast: Start in the pan, flip & transfer to grill, start another. Move the first to a plate, second to the grill. Add more batter to a pan, fill the first with fruit and such, by the time it was done, the next crepes were ready to move down the assembly line! VERY fast!

text:
I don't know why, but I think this recipe comes together even more easily than "blender crêpes"...maybe because you only have to clean a whisk and a bowl, rather than a blender. I'd never considered starting with just the eggs and flour. Now, I won't do it any other way. I add the liquid when the eggs and flour are starting to get thick, just before they clog up in my whisk. 

I was well into my meal at the 30 minute mark. Hurrah!

As with pancakes and eggs, the secret is really your pan: getting a good cooking surface (not too much fat on it) and the right temperature. Practice makes perfect; as as you do them, you'll get the hang of these things. The French chef who taught me how to make crêpes insisted that you don't need a spatula-you can use your fingers if you're nimble enough. I tend to agree. A splash of liqueur (think Grand  Marnier, though I enjoy using lychee myself) or rum in your batter adds flair to dessert crêpes.

The "icing on the crêpe," so to speak, is that this recipe is so flexible: you can make dessert crêpes, dinner crêpes filled with any number of wonderful things, or even use the recipe as the base for blintzes.

I make them every Sunday for breakfast.

HOWEVER, YOU NEED TO PUT THE milk in first, then the melted butter, then eggs.
I also add vanilla extract and turn the heat down to like a 4-5 on my stove to keep them from browning.

You can add a little more milk if you like them thiner, like we do.

I put butter on them and sprinkle sugar on them and roll them up. My hubby likes jelly/jam in them.

None
text:
the trick is to make a well in the flour and put the eggs in there, whisk them and allow the flour to add itself in. it does take some time (and effort). then, slowly add in the milk, like a pour at a time, then the water a pour at a time. dumping it all together will make a lumpy mess. 
The trick to frying (crepes or pancakes) is to have your skillet/griddle HOT and pre-greased (butter, bacon grease, shortening, coconut oil) before even trying to put anything in it. It should be almost smoky, if not smoky, before you pour your batter. You'll never lose that first one if you just let your pan get searing hot first. And be sure you drop another spoon of your greasing agent between each batter pour, and allow it to melt and get hot THEN pour your batter in. Again- it's a time consuming endeavor, but if you want perfection this is the way to go.
Great recipe! Thank you!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good basic recipe.  Notes and tips though: 1. I recommend adding more milk/water to get a thinner mixture. 2. Being able to spread the batter in the skillet/cooking surface is vital if you want super-thin results. 3. If you end up with lumpy batter run it through a strainer, cheesecloth is too fine and will clog up from the batter alone. 4. I ended up using a large bowl with spout/handle and pouring the batter directly. 5. I would NOT cook the first side for 2 minuets as the recipe says, 20-30 seconds does the trick on mid-high. 6. If your spatula is sticking have a cloth ready to dry it between crepes.  7. If you're sufficiently quick you don't need a spatula to remove the crepe from the pan at the end. 8. Thinner batter yields more crepes than the recipe suggests.   9. De-lish

I used this recipe to make crepes for the very first time in my life, and it was wonderful and easy.  Other recipes I've seen (like on FoodNetwork) call for you to put ingredients in a blender and "pulse for 10 seconds." text:
These are quick and easy to make.  Do, however, mix the wet stuff first, before adding the salt and flour to the liquid.  Otherwise, you end up with a lumpy (but tasty) mess.
I use a cast-iron griddle, over med-low flame, and it is imperative that you roll the griddle around to distribute the batter.  If you do that, you get nice thin, almost see-through, crepes.  The edges curl up when it is time to flip them, and they stay in tact during the flip.
Overall, a great recipe, but the mixing steps are a little off....

text:
This is our favorite crepe recipe. It took a time or two to figure out how exactly to make the perfect crepe but you will get it. I had to learn to spread it thin, I can't use soy milk and I needed a perfect size frying pan to create them in.

Also you need to either add all the ingredients and mix, or add all the wet and then sift in the flour. You do NOT want to mix in flour and egg and then add the other ingredients or it will make the batter lumpy. You want it watery!

Also we always add vanilla extract to ours. It gives it a nice flavor.

text:
This was my very first time making crepes, but based on other reviews I made a couple of changes. I mixed the wet ingredients first (made more sense) and I added a teaspoon of vanilla extract and about 4 tablespoons of powdered sugar (to me powdered made more sense so that it blends in better). I used almond milk instead of regular, mostly because the regular milk was questionable and I wasn't sure if it was still good. I also sifted the flour as I added it in and I did that in 3 parts. They came out just perfect! Super thin and slightly crispy on the edges. And I didn't have to add more liquid like others had said. Overall, this is a great and easy recipe to use as a base and then customize to your liking.

userID:
1629399
Display Name:
qj
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Our family visited Paris a couple of weeks ago and I think this recipe makes crepes better than most that we tried in Paris! I made the batter the night before and in the morning just took it out of the fridge and thin it up further with about 1/4 cup of milk. This is a trick my French friend told me. Her mom makes great crepes and she always chills the batter for at least an hour and then thin it out further with milk. I haven't tried without doing this so I can't compare, but this method definitely gave me really great crepes. Another notes for those who have trouble with getting lumps after adding the milk to the doughy mixture of flour and eggs: at the beginning just add small amount of milk (maybe 1/4-1/3 cup) at a time and stir until the mixture is smooth. When the mixture is more like liquid than dough you can add the rest of the milk. I used a whisk instead of a hand-held mixer and it took me some work but I did end up with a very smooth batter.  YAY for not having to go to France for great crepes! I am going to make this again this weekend. Can't wait!

Unusable as written! You can NOT mix the eggs and flour first! This leaves you with a wasted clumpy substance. First mix the water, milk and melted butter, gradually sift in the flour, then whip the eggs in a separate bowl, and stir into the mixture. I add 1/3 tsp vanilla for added flavour.

userID:
1469911
Display Name:
rharris
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good basic crepe recipe.  I omit the salt and add vanilla, and I blend all of the ingredients simultaneously, as others have suggested.  Also, I do not turn the crepes; I prefer thinner crepes, so I add enough liquid to make them thin enough so that they cook completely without the need to turn them.  As an aside, the 20 minute cook time in the recipe is a typo--they cook easily within 2 minutes. It's easy to prep AND cook them in 10 minutes total!  For those who have not tried making crepes, it's incredibly easy in a skillet--much easier than the electric crepe makers that require dipping the appliance into the batter.  I had an electric crepe maker and hated making crepes; switching to a non-stick skillet totally changed my attitude.

text:
This recipe was fantastic except I had some problems with the consistency.  It seemed to be too thick.  When I was rolling the pan around, the batter took a long time to reach the edge of the pan so the first couple of crepes cooked before I was able to get the right shape/size.  When it came time to flip, they would fold mid-air, which told me they were too thick and heavy.  To resolve this, I added about 3/4 cup liquid (equal parts milk and water).  This fixed the problem.  They turned out perfectly light and delicious.  I would probably leave the recipe as is if I was making savory crepes rather than sweet.  It would make them more like pancakes and heartier for heavier fillings.  These I served with strawberries and powdered sugar.  I also added some vanilla to the batter (maybe a teaspoon or so).  Perfection!

text:
I happen to have this recipe at home and love it!  The only difference is that I layer them in that order in a blender.  Blend for 30 seconds, scrape down the sides of the blender, and then blend for 60 seconds.  Let the batter rest a few minutes before making.  Never any lumps.  We also double the recipe (since it's a favorite).  A double batch works perfectly in the blender.

i love the way that these turn out but only gave it 4 stars because the directions are a little upside down.  I tried it as the recipe directs exactly and came out with lumpy batter despite all my attempts to fix it.  I tried it again this morning being sure to this time mix all the wet ingredients including eggs together and then added in the dry and they came out perfectly.  I also didn't bother to grease my non-stick pan as I noticed that the first time round my crepes were a little greasy.  This time they turned out much better without greasing the pan.  I got about 8 crepes from my batter in case you're wondering how many "4 servings" will give you. I might try them next time with a little more water to make them easier to swirl in the pan.

text:
This is a solid recipe that says it all in the name - BASIC crepes. It's not original or overly exciting, but it is a perfect starting point. For some zest in the crepe itself, you can add almond or lemon extract, or cinnamon, pumpkin spice, or allspice for a sweeter crepe, or a good, hard cheese like Parmesan, or hot sauce, or any number of spices for a savory crepe. When I want crepes, this is my starting point, and from there, the only limit is my imagination.

BelleoftheBalle

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE! The best crepes I've ever had, and so easy to make! Even when I make them too thick, they always cook completely in the middle and don't burn as easily as other crepes (no runny middles/burnt edges). 

I make a lower fat/calorie version by using skim milk instead of regular and reducing the water (by half) to 1/4 cup so the batter won't be too runny. I also omit the butter completely. I've tried the two versions - with and without butter - side by side, and neither myself nor my father, even when we tried, could tell the difference. They also turn out well using 1/2 cup of egg substitute instead of 2 real eggs, BUT most of the time I choose to use real eggs because I feel the noticeably richer flavor justifies the extra fat and calories. 

I dump all the ingredients in my stand mixer, add the whisk attachment, and let it run until all the lumps are gone. I spray the pan fairly lightly with cooking spray before beginning and never have to re-oil. Enjoy!

userID:
2719005
Display Name:
Tay
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a stovetop wok for this recipe, and discovered quickly that in a stovetop wok (one with good teflon) you do not need the butter in the pan and can cook them quickly and effectively if you use med-high heat.

Excellent recipe, but I did make a couple small alterations.  First off, I blended all of the liquid ingredients and the salt together (also adding a small amount of sugar) until smooth and uniform, then added the flour about a 6th of a cup at a time, blending fully each time to get a very smooth batter.  I've done this with any crepe recipe since I was about 10 (I've been making these for about 10 years).  At this point, I found the batter was too thick to get good, transparent crepes, so I added a small amount more milk and water and blended thoroughly.  

They turned out PERFECTLY after I discovered the trick with my wok.  My partner, who is from French-Canadian descent, as I am, and grew up on good crepes, was VERY impressed and wants me to make them again tomorrow.  We ate them simply--butter and jam for him and butter and maple syrup for me--and tomorrow we're going to make "dessert" crepes with cut up fruit and whipped cream.

Awesome recipe, after the alterations I made.  The same as the traditional recipe I learned as a small child--I even had to make precisely the same alterations to get the results I wanted!  I've personally never bothered with the wait times for traditional crepes and get as good results.

text:
This is the very recipe I lost. I usually put the ingredients into the blender with the eggs on the bottom, flour in the middle and remaining ingredients on top and blend it until smooth. This method removes the possibility of lumps that some have mentioned. You many need to scrape the sides of the blender once to ensure all the flour is mixed in. I do add a bit of vanilla sugar to the recipe to add a hint of sweetness.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an easy and delicious recipe. Based on the comments/suggestions, I have a few warnings. Another reviewer suggested putting a pat of butter in the pan before pouring in the batter. Don't do this if you are using a non-stick pan. That will make the batter roll around when you are trying to coat the pan with it. Second, as another reviewer suggested, mix all the wet ingredients together, then sift in the flower. Doing it the way the recipe suggests, makes for a lumpy batter; not unworkable, but not pretty. Tastes delicious as sweet breakfast crepes. To save time you can serve it with a fruit compote. Cheers!

text:
I made these for breakfast today but halved the recipe for me and my hubby. After reading the reviews, I mixed the dry ingredients together, mixed the wet ingredients and then mixed the two. I also added 1/2 tbsp of sugar (for sweet crepes) and added an extra 1/8 cup of water to make the batter runnier. They cooked very quickly and they didn't break! :D. I managed to make 4. I had mine with lemon and sugar and my hubby had his with maple syrup. This is the 2nd crepe recipe i have tried and it is the BEST! Will definitely be making these again!

I forgot to bake a loaf of bread for the kids to have PB&J today so I was looking for something else we could use as a substitute.  I have wanted to try crepes for a while and this recipe was quick, just what I needed!  They were a huge hit.  The kids ate them all and I had to make another batch. We ate them with peanut butter and banana, PB and applesauce, PB and apple butter, garden vegetable cream cheese and pepperoni... They thought of all sorts of fillings for the next time we have them.  My 4 yr old asked me to make them every day! (One note: I made about 10 10-12" crepes from this recipe.  Each of my 5 kids ages 1-12 ate at least 2, you might want to double up if you are cooking for more than 2-3 people.) Thanks for the great and EASY recipe!

pretty good recipe, easy to adapt and fill with whatever. But for good Crepes,  the trick is to mix them in the blender, and then let it sit for at least two hours in the fridge!  Makes them light and airy :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this recipe and it’s wonderful.  I made Crepas de Cajeta: translation—caramel crepes.  I added a little sugar and a little vanilla.  I mixed by hand and then mixed in a blender to smooth the batter out.  If you like Dulce de leche ice cream, then cajeta (I like the cajeta quemada) is for you.  It’s a Mexican caramel that comes in a plastic container (like pancake syrup) and you can find it in grocery stores.  Fold each crepe in half and then fold over again. Pour heated cajeta over the crepes and add some chopped pecans…ummm.
A nice substitute is Nutella--make the same way using heated Nutella and top with pecans if you like and some whipped cream.

city:

country:
None
text:
I enjoyed this recipe. I missplaced my go-to low calorie one, so used this one in the meantime. I do make some changes to the recipe to make the crepes more flavorful: 

add
1 tsp granulated cane sugar
1-1/2 tsp ground cinnamon
1 tsp vanilla extract

I also take the tip from other reviewers and mix the wet ingredients first, then add the dry ingredients. Otherwise you end with a doughy, hard to mix mess. These are wonderful, today will be my third time using the recipe. :) 

Filling:
My go-to filling is nutella, banana slices, and strawberry slices with a small drizzle of cocoa powder, with a spritz of low-fat whipped cream topping: delicious.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made crepes using this recipe numerous times. The main reason why  I went to IHOP one day and they took out the stuffed french toast and I had to settle with an alternative so I chose strawberry crepes, which I was disappointed with. All I tasted in my mouth was eggs. I absolutely love this recipe is the fact that there is no egg aftertaste, it's not eggy and it's light. You can play with this recipe and not mess it up (in terms of adding ingredients in). I added about a teaspoon of vanilla extract, a dash of nutmeg and about 1/4- 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon. It comes out great. I sometimes add sugar, but being that the filling I put in the crepes is usually sweet I don't want to over do it with the sugar. So now I make my own Strawberry Crepes with cream cheese filling at home at the time!! I get the filling from this other recipe on this site. Here's the Link for those who are interested: http://allrecipes.com/recipe/creamy-strawberry-crepes/

This is an excellent basic crepe recipe. I like that  there is no sugar in the recipe so these crepes can be used for savory or sweet creations. I mixed it differently- combine the dry ingredients, combine eggs, milk and water, then added that to the dry. Then added the melted butter.  These cooked up so easily and using a non-stick pan I didn't need additional fat. Excellent!

text:
i really like this crepe because as it is cooked, it's chewy and crispy at the edge:D I followed the exact recipe but i did add a tablespoon of sugar to give it a better taste. And I ate this for breakfast!

I also made caramelised apple cinnamon filling. To make apple cinnamon filling, add 1 tbsp butter in a saucepan above medium heat, then add 1 red apple (cubed), 1/2 tbsp sugar, 1/2 tbsp honey, 1/4 tsp cinnamon. Cook for five minutes until apples are cooked but a bit crispy (I like the apples not too soft). After all, this is my first attempt and it worked!

text:
This is a great recipe. I have made this over 10 times now and it is so good. I used to eat the crepes at IHOP all the time and I am so glad I can make this at home now. Each time I follow the recipe but to the batter I also add 1/4 cup powdered sugar and 1 tsp vanilla extract and 1 tbsp honey. I like the flavor it adds. By using a hand mixer to combine you will get the smoothest batter. I usually top mine with fresh strawberry, blueberry, and blackberry. If I dont have fresh fruit I will use the raspberry preserve I always keep on hand. Top with syrup for the most indulgent breakfast ever!

text:
This is a great crepe recipe! It's simple and easy, and made from ingredients that everyone has on hand. However, I did have to make some small adjustments. First, I always have to add extra milk and water to get the batter to the right consistency. Also, I add a couple spoonfuls of sugar to the batter to make it just a little bit sweeter. We serve this with my special banana filling. ( Fry sliced bananas in 1 Tbsp. of butter, add 1 Tbsp. of honey, and sprinkle with brown sugar and grated coconut. Fry just until soft.) This is truly a great recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Recipe sounds great and I want to try it. One tip (lived in france for a few years and had many friends show me crepe-making tips) Don't mix ALL the eggs and flour at once. Crack the eggs into the side of the bowl of flour or make a well to put them in. Use beaters or a wire wisk to beat the eggs with the flour around it gradually. Add the milk (I've never used water) to the soft mixture, gradually mixing in the flour. You don't want lumps, so avoid mixing in the flour too fast. This keeps the consistency just right.

text:
Well I'm not the worst cook, and definitely not the best, but I made some great crepes today from this recipe! I usually look at the reviews of a recipe I get from this site.  Specifically the most helpful reviews.  I did as I read others did and used 1 Tablespoon of sugar, added 1 Tablespoon of vanilla, then  added some cinnamon (I just sprinkled it in the batter and then did the same with my jar of nutmeg.) I tossed a bit of milk into the batter to thin it as it looked a bit like pancake batter. I used fresh strawberries that I cut up and tossed with a little powdered sugar for the filling. I used a non-stick frying pan and used butter flavored cooking spray too. I filled them with the strawberries, rolled and sprinkled the tops with powdered sugar, used some pancake syrup.  They were easy to make. They were so good I made them twice today for myself.  The extra batter that I put in the frig after making them the first time didn't even have a chance ;)

userID:
1292577
Display Name:
Los Gofres
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
25
favoritesCount:
191
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/173523.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love how simple and elegant these can be. This recipe made me famous among my friends--I would make them all the time and people would beg me for them. It's all about the filling though; my favorite is to sautee apples (Spitzenbergs are my favorite) in pressed apple cider with allspice, cardamom, nutmeg and cinnamon, reserve some of the juice, mix that with some candied walnuts or pecans and use homemade whipped cream to fill it. Mmmm..... For something more savory, I will make a "Crepe Benedictine" and chop up some poached eggs, canadian bacon and pour hollandaise sauce over the top. I also loved to macerate strawberries and mix them with strawberry-raspberry jam. For dessert, sometimes I will put some cocoa powder in the batter stuff the crepe with strawberries and a Kahlua chocolate sauce. It's absolutely divine.

text:
These are very good...nice, thin, golden crepes.  I filled them with sliced bananas, topped them with sliced strawberries and touch of sour cream, and drizzled them with the orange sauce recipe from this website.  My husband had them with maple syrup.  We both liked them. The only thing I recommend, differently, is to first mix together the milk & water & eggs, THEN add the flour because just mixing the flour & eggs alone and adding liquids after, makes a globby ball that is hard to break down again!  Thanks for sharing this, Jen.

This is a really good recipe, and I'm not even a huge crepe fan. Just had a craving, so decided to try my hand at a basic recipe. I found Christine Anderson's suggestion of adding a 1/4 cup of sugar to the batter did the trick-- Lovely, light, with just a touch of sweetness--and oh, so quick!

country:

text:
DELICIOUS!!! Followed some of the suggestions and beat the eggs in with the milk and water instead, then sifted the flour in gradually as I whisked it. I then added the salt and melted butter and whisked it until it was a really lovely smooth batter. The first one was a bit thick, but after I got the hang of adding the batter to the pan and tilting it quickly, it flowed around to make a lovely, thin crepe. They don't take long to cook, mine were a lovely golden brown at a minute each side. I served them by spreading some Nutella onto it, arranging some sliced strawberries and folding it up burrito style. It was every bit as good as the wonderful crepe cafe near our house. One could probably add sifted confectioner's sugar or whipped cream as well, but I loved them just the way they were. We are going to try doing a savoury version next and attempt replicating the cafe's "Philly Cheesesteak" version with thinly sliced roast beef, slivered red pepper, thinly sliced red onion, spinach, and grated cheese. YUM!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made these several times and they are delicious! I halve the recipe to make just 3-4 crepes for me for breakfast. I don't bother with what order to put the ingredients in - I just dump everything into my 2 cup glass measuring cup and whisk. Never had any lump issues. I tend to add a little vanilla and sometimes a little white sugar since I love them sweet. My favorite filling is ricotta cheese mixed with brown sugar, top with a little butter and drizle with pure maple syrup. I made bananas foster (chop a banana and dump into a pan with some butter and brown sugar - heat to bubbling - add a little rum if you want) to top them with one day too and they were heavenly! Make sure your pan is hot enough and you swirl the batter around it in right after you pour it in to make it thin. Wait until the edges of the crepe turn brown and they are perfect every time. Nice and thin and crispy.

text:
Okay so I followed the directions exactly and was really excited as I never made crepes before. The first two crepes didn't look so hot but after i got the spreading technique down they really started to look like restaurant style crepes! I was happy that I learned to make this kind of fancy dish and it was remarkably easy. Then I tasted one of the crepes...BLECH!! I'm sorry but don't you have to put sugar, vanilla or something? I actually added in a little vanilla and cinnamon at the beginning, even though the recipe did call for it, it still tasted so bland. I added more vanilla, more cinnamon and some almond extract and sugar, okay it was getting better but still didn't taste like the crepes I get in the restaurants.

I ended up throwing what was left of the crepe batter into what was left of the pancake batter I had stored which already had cinnamon, almond extract and vanilla extract. Now we're talking! They tasted great and my son loved them with some apple pie filling and whipped cream, but as the original recipe stood, I don't get how it got so many high reviews. The taste was flavorless without even a bit of sweetness in it.

VictoriaSe49896

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was in the mood for crepes but couldn't find my go to recipe so I decided to use this one. Not remembering the ingredient amounts I followed this one to the T even though others said it was thick. First off the medium-high heat is too high. If you choose to try this recipe you should cook them on medium heat. The mixture is too thick and essentially makes an omelet. While trying to save this recipe and make a good crepe I added another egg and a tbsp of milk. Even this combined with my immersion blender and cutting back on the amount cooked didn't help completely. A good crepe should be light and airy with a light golden brown appearance. When making one you should drop just enough mixture to swirl and coat the bottom of the pan. I knew when I saw the cooking time something was wrong because it should take 30 seconds - 1 minute for your crepe to cook before being flipped. If you're in the mood for an omelet this makes a decent one but not a crepe. The cook time, ingredient amounts and heat setting are all off, I won't make this again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe. I've been making creeps for years and couldn't find my recipe so I tried this one. I find this makes a thicker crepe than I prefer so I added an additional 2 to 4 tbsp of milk. This made a nice, thin crepe. Also, I find it easiest to put all the ingredients in a blender, adding the flour last, and mixing it that way. This makes a very smooth batter and pours easily. Another tip is to use the size of pan than you would like your creeps to be. Then you can just swirl the batter to the edges for nice, round crepes. I agree with the reviewers than suggest to add some butter to the pan before adding the batter- either for every crepe, or even every second crepe if you have a good pan. I take the whole pound of butter with the wrapper peeled back a little and swipe it quickly around the pan. I like to cut of some bananas and strawberries and fold the crepe up then finish with a drizzle of chocolate or syrup! Yum!

I gave this recipe 5 stars because I think it would be great as written; I was looking for a recipe I could modify to be non-dairy and this was pretty good. I used Almond milk, Smart Balance butter, and added almost 1/4 cup sugar (to our taste). These were fairly easy to handle, although didn't flip too easily, and the taste/texture were ok with our toppings. Maybe less melted butter next time, since I needed plenty in the skillet to prevent sticking. Thanks!

text:
This recipe was great! I decided to make a different dessert because we always have pie or ice cream. During a food festival in Downton Long Beach, CA, my husband and I had the opportunity to try different local eateries; and one of them was La Creperie. I instantly fell in love with it and wanted more! I tried this recipe for the first time with the ingredients listed plus 1/2 tsp of vanilla extract and ground cinnamon for flavor. It was delish! My husband loved it and so does our 4yr old! I also filled the inside with nutella and bananas then top with more bananas, chocolate syrup and powered sugar. Simple recipe with simple, cheap ingredients - great for this low budget mom! Two thumbs way up!! :)

text:
My mother used to make these when I was a child, I made them for my children and now my grandson!  We have always called them "Special Pancackes"!  The only changes are omit the water and increase the milk to 1 1/2 cups, and add a little more flour if the batter is too thin.  We serve with jelly in the center, roll up, pour on a little warmed maple syrup, sprinkle with powder sugar and slivered almonds!  DELISH!!!

text:
It was super easy and fun to do. I made them first for my boyfriend and then demonstrated it for my speech class. Everyone loved it and then afterwards we had a crepe party in my dorm. (: Now my sister can make them in Japan, since the ingredients are super simple. Did the wet stuff first, then flour. I added sugar and vanilla extract for the dessert ones, but left out for the savory ones. You don't need to oil the pan, the butter "oils" it for you and doesn't stick at all. Just flip when the edges crisp and you can shake the crepe around the pan. Tastes AMAZING with habanero cheddar cheese, pastrami and arugula!

Display Name:
Cedarglen

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Outstanding recipe - for a dirt-simple food.  It works and tastes great.  My variation is adding a pinch of NETMEG, about 1 tsp sugar (even for savory) and using all whole milk (no water) for the fluid component.  These are rich enough to have some flavor of their own and to be a bit more than soft, warm 'bread' to hold something else.  They are fun and tasty as-is.  If making a double batch, to feed several, I cook the crepes with two pans and hold them in a 150-200 degree oven, folden in half and covered with a damp paper towel.    Another tip:  Don't try to stir out the lumps; not worth the trouble and it will toughen the final crepe.  Better practice is to make thej batter 8-24 hours ahead of time and fridge it, stiring lightly when it comes out.  Any lumps will be gone.  The FUN thing about crepes is that they can be eaten alone - or filled with virtually anything.  Go for it!  -Cedarglen

text:
First time making crepes, surprised how easy they were to make! Thanks to the other reviews, I also mixed the eggs in with the other ingredients, then added the flour. I used whole wheat flour, and added about 1/4 sugar to the batter, and they turned out quite well. In the future I think I'll stick to white flour for dessert crepes, and whole wheat for savory/veggie crepes though! Taste was still great, but the texture of the whole wheat was a bit much for a dessert crepe.

I was looking for an easy crepe recipe one day, and I stumbled across this one in my search. It looked so simple, I just had to try it! Overall, this is an amazing recipe with basic ingriedients you already have in your pantry!

Let rest for 30-60 min. (I tested one before and after. Less rubbery after a rest)  Added 2 Tbsp sugar to make them sweet and 1.5 Tbsp water to thin & for the Colorado altitude.  
For some reason this batter coats the pan easier than other recipes I have used - but not too thick.  Will be my new crepe recipe.  Thanks!  
P.S. My 11 yr old daughter helped make them to share with a european themed Girl Scout meeting.Due to the sugar, they were even great plain. I have been asked to make a double batch next time and her friends request them when they come over to play!

text:
In the 60's, I used my best crepe recipe for appetizers and petite desserts,  which was 1/2 c flour, 1/2 c milk and 2 egg yolks to make 12 5-6 inch crepes.  Wanting to make 8" crepes for a fruit dessert and not use 8 yolks, I used this recipe doubled rather than quading my tried recipe.  Other reviews - too thick, too thin....I find this perfect.  I doubled to 2 C flour, 1 1/2 c 2% milk + 1/2 c water,  everything else the same.  PERFECT. Made 10 8" crepes. Now this is my keeper!

text:
I used butter flavored cooking spray in the pan. I added 1 teaspoon vanilla and 1 tablespoon of sugar as suggested by many. They are quick, easy and delicious. I prepared some strawberry sauce by heating diced strawberries with a little tiny bit of water, a few tablespoons of sugar and about one teaspoon diluted cornstarch. I filled the crepes with this sauce , rolled them and dusted them with powdered sugar....Voila! / Made them without adding anything to the batter and it works very well as is too. If you intend to use them with a sweet filling or topping, I would make as is so that they whole dish is not too sweet. The batter comes out a bit thicker than I would prefer but it still works very well. I made a blackberry compote, filled with vanilla pudding and topped with fresh berries and whipped cream. Very good!

text:
These are the BEST and EASIEST crepes ever.  I modified a bit to suit our tastes by adding a dash of vanilla and about 2 teas. sugar to the batter and mixing it with a hand mixer to avoid any lumps, and they were great.  We topped them with sliced strawberries that had been sprinkled with a little sugar and left to sit while the crepes cooked. Did the same with blueberries that we had on hand. Then rolled them, sprinkled with powdered sugar and topped with a little whipped cream.  WONDERFUL, Elegant and Easy.  You can also make the batter the night before and refrigerate if you're in a hurry.  My youngest likes to eat them right out of the pan!  He's also heated leftover crepes in the microwave, wrapped sliced ham and cheese in them and made a quick snack or weekend lunch with the leftovers :)  Easy, great tasing and versatile too!

text:
This was my first time trying to make crepes and found this recipe to be easy to follow and easy to make. I modified the recipe slightly to add more flavor. I added about 1/8 cup sugar, 2 teaspoons vanilla, 1 teaspoon cinnamon and 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg. The flavor was amazing! I cooked them in an 8 inch skillet to make them small, using about 1/8 cup of batter for each. Then I mixed 8 ounces cream cheese and some mixed berries with a little sugar (to taste) to knock off the bitterness as a filling. Then I rolled them and topped them with powdered sugar. Whipped Cream would have made them awesome, too! Definately a keeper recipe!

OHIOMOM1

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making & eating crepes. I admit I was intimidated, but I needn't have been though, this was super easy! My English husband who has had the genuine thing agreed that we loved them! 
The trick to making them "the authentic way" is to pour a tiny bit of batter (no where near as much as 1/4 cup) and then dump the rest back into your mix to get them thin and crispy on the edges. We used a 6" non-stick skillet and didn't use any oil and didn't have any problems w/ sticking. 
My husband ate them w/ plain yogurt & fruit, I ate them w/ butter (margarine) and powdered (confectioners') sugar. Delicious! Just the right consistency: light & fluffy, not too sweet goodness. I can only eat 1 pancake because of the heaviness, but ate quite a lot of these! They yielded about 25, 5-inch crepes.
As suggested, we added 1/2 tsp. of vanilla extract to the wet ingredients.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried a few crepe recipes and this was the best.  I made three batches of crepes (40 crepes) for a neighborhood progressive brunch. Things I learned: real butter is the best and the pan only need a very light re-coat; I use a blender to mix and then pop it into the fridge for an hour but if I leave in the fridge for two hours, it will be a little too think; A mid grade 8" no stick pan works fine and the white ceramic ones caused some difficulty.  I switched to using a pitcher to pour a scant 1/4 cup into the pan. It was faster. Practice with pan was a winning move. I served four different recipes: savory chicken; sweet riccotta with peaches and cognac; Nutella with strawberries and lastly cream cheese with berries.

I used whole wheat flour. Not exact texture like bleached white, but still turned out nicely and healthy too. Also, I mixed all liquids first using my vitamix, then added dry ingredients. No lumps. Not sure why instructions say to mix eggs and flour first. I used my electric flat griddle on 200 degrees and did not have to use oil. Make sure you spread the batter super duper thin.

text:
Delicious! I didn't have to make any changes, but if you are eating these plain, you may want to add vanilla to give the crepes a little flavor. I like to serve mine with fried bananas (1 sliced banana tossed in a cinnamon/nutmeg/sugar mixture and lightly fried in butter), and top with homemade whipped cream (cold heavy whipping cream sweetened with a little bit of maple syrup). This recipe is the perfect base for whatever topping you plan on adding!

userID:
15310532
Display Name:
Barbara Molin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
40
favoritesCount:
268
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2033672.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use low fat milk so skip the water and increase milk to 1 1/2 cups for thinner batter. I also add 1 teaspoon of sugar to the recipe if I am making sweet crepes. I mix all the ingredients in a quart mason jar using an immersion blender and this way I can put the lid on to store any leftover batter saving on dishes. My family loves them for breakfast stuffed with fruit and maple syrup. I do miss my old crepe pan though that I could dip in the batter rather than pour for yet thinner crepes. I would recommend having two pans on the go if you have a large family like I do (7). Also, be careful not to overcook these as they become stiff and crispy and difficult to roll. On the other hand if they are too thick then they become more difficult to cook right through.

userID:
12738959
Display Name:
Jasmine

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great. I picked it because of another review by a chef that instructed using butter instead of oil in the batter so that the crepes carmelize.  Additionally this review mentioned that sifting(therby aerating the flour)'is a must and the pan should be hot. All tips right on the money.  A big thank you to the person with these tips. While this is a great recipe, not specifying either weight or sifting for the flour used will make for very mixed results.

A couple of my own tips:
     - I used a stainless steel pan, heated it up to medium hot(water sizzles but pan is not smoking). Getting the right pan is tricky. Use Pam for the first one and for further crepes only as necesary.
     -  Use a pan you can actually pick up to roll while spreading the batter. Be prepared to roll the pan as you pour the batter. I found that pouring the batter towards the edge of the pan away from you is best and tilt the pan towards you when you pour - this makes the crepe thinner and more even.
      - Keep some water next to you when making the crepes. You may need to thin the batter to get to the crepes right. Add water a tablespoon at a time. Before you pour the batter into the pan, mix the batter each time - it will thicken  at the bottom.

Lastly, don't bother with the multi-step mixing process - just put all ingredients in a bowl and mix with a whisk.

text:
This recipe was OK for BASIC crepes. However, the batter (like many reviewers have said) was VERY lumpy and hard to deal with. I had to squeeze the flour with my hands to get it to flatten out. I ended up wasting batter and straining it. 

Taste was excellent; I just had lumpy parts that would have tasted weird if I hadn't topped them with nutella.

All in all: this was ok for very basic crepes; I would have def. changed the order of flour and eggs and the other ingredients. Add flour last if you want to try this recipe.

VouxDouxDoll

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1043946.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go-to crepe recipe. If I'm just making sweet crepes I add some sugar to the mix. They freeze wonderfully if you place a piece of wax paper between each one and then put in a zippy bag. You can peel off as many as you want and by the time your morning tea has brewed your crepes are thawed. Also, there is no need for a special crepe pan, just get a regular non-stick pan and never ever use anything metal on it, the scratches are what makes the crepes stick. My pan is only used for crepes and the only utensil I use on it is a wooden chopstick to free up a stuck edge. As soon as the crepe begins to move easily around the pan when you shake it a bit it's ready to flip. After a few practice flips you'll be flipping them like an old diner cook in no time :)

text:
I did a few things different, as others have stated I mixed the wet ingredients first then sifted in the flour.  My son is allergic to dairy so I did some substitutions.  I used almond milk in place of the regular milk, butter flavoring in place of the butter but half of the amount(can be found in with the specialty cake decorating) and zero calorie Sprite in place of the water (this added a little lime to the batter).  I also used cooking spray instead of oil in my pan.  We added chopped strawberries with a little bit of sugar on them that had been slightly mashed to the top. For those of use who were not allergic to the dairy I made a whip cream/cream cheese filling which is 8 oz cream cheese mixed until smooth first, one small container of whip cream, 1/3 c of sugar and 1 t vanilla, mixed until smooth. 30 very happy breakfast eaters.

country:

text:
I agree with Morley that you should add everything together or at least add the flour last. Mixing just the flour and eggs makes a very thick pasta dough, which is basically impossible to fully break up when you add the liquids. I wound up having to pour my mix through a strainer because there were so many clumps in there. The video tells you to add all the ingredients together. (Button right below the photo). Wish I had seen that before I made these! I also added a quarter cup of confectionary sugar to make it sweet for a dessert. I put a pat of butter in the pan between each crepe, which made them simply ethereal. Delicious, easy recipe that I will make again and again.

text:
Unfortunately, this recipe didn't work out well for me. The crepes were thick, tasteless and rubbery (after reading several reviews, I wasn't the only one with this problem). I made it as per the video where all ingredients expect the butter are mixed together all at once and then butter is added at the end. I had stacked them up with chocolate pudding between each layer and dusted with cocoa powder before serving. I kept it in the fridge for several hours and left it at room temperature for a while before serving. When I bit into it, I was surprised that the crepes were rubbery. No one had seconds, and I ended up throwing the rest out the next day. Unfortunately, I won't be making this recipe again. I find the rating very misleading. There are better crepe recipes on this site that are closer to what a real crepe should taste like (thin and lacy).

text:
Absolutely LOVED. I did mix the wet ingredients first and then added the flour last. I also added 2 tablespoons of powdered sugar since I know I was going to use these as dessert crapes. I'm from Europe and this is exactly the way my mom makes it. DELICIOUS!!! Also this amount made about 6 or 7 crapes so if you are making this for more people I suggest doubling the ingredients. It stores well in the fridge or freezer between wax paper.

text:
simple, basic recipe. you can add vanilla to the batter or whatever you want. I use my round cast iron griddle but any nonstick pan will work, and according to the joy of cooking, you can leave the batter in the fridge for up to 2 days (covered of course) so long as you let it come to room temp for 30 minutes before using. I served mine today with just a little sugar and lemon but pretty much anything works with a crepe except for....ok I can't think of anything that won't work with a crepe. What a diverse food!

country:
None
text:
I make these all the time for my family. I use a microwave safe mixing bowl to melt the butter, then throw in the water then milk, then the eggs, then the flour and just wisk it all together - turns out beautifully every time. Also, I use a wide flipper or a counter scraper to spread the crepe out in the pan after pouring batter in - rinse between each crepe - and they are always as thick or as thin as we'd like!

text:
These crepes were so easy and delicious!  I followed the recipe exactly, although my batter did come out a little lumpy as some reviews stated.  Next time, I will try what one user suggested of mixing the eggs and wet ingredients and then sifting in the flour. 
 I also thought that these were just a bit too thick for crepes.  Next time, I might add an additional 1/4 cup of milk.
I served these stuffed with bacon, scrambled eggs and sharp cheddar cheese inside.  They were fantastic!

text:
These turned out perfectly!  I did what other people suggested and mixed the wet ingredients first and then stirred in the flour.  Right after you flip them, you can layer in ham and cheese or veggies and then fold them over to warm/melt everything.  Yum!  I also made sweet ones with Nutella and sliced banana, and others with lemon curd.  They were a hit.  I have tried other crepe recipes before, but none were nearly this successful!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!  Easy, and delicious!  What a treat!  Per another suggestion, I added 1/3 cup granulated sugar and 1.4 cup powdered sugar to the batter.  Amazing.  I also followed another suggestion and blended the "wet" ingredients first, and then slowly added the "dry" ingredients to this to avoid lumpiness.  It worked well.  If you still have lumps, just wait fine minutes and whisk again... they should all have absorbed.  I initially served these with fresh strawberries, jam, and a dusting of powdered sugar, but found that they were amazing with JUST the powdered sugar on top.  What a treat and SO easy!

text:
very easy and tasty recipe! I put everything in my food processor and mixed it up, added 1 tbsp vanilla sugar and a dash of cinnamon. I also heated the water and milk in the microwave which really helps make a smooth batter, sometimes I do need to add an extra 1 tbsp of water depending on the time of year. 
Double recipe with 1/3 cup measure makes 11 crepes, 1 minute on each side.
Filled with jam and sprinkled with cinnamon sugar.

These were the perfect texture! Your instructions were also helpful; I'd never made crepes before, so with your instructions and the advice of a friend to flip when it had a "delicate lace pattern," these crepes were perfection. I had to REALLY beat them to smooth the batter out, and I also used a cup of fat free milk instead of half milk and half water. I added 1.5 tablespoons of white sugar to make them desert crepes. Heavenly!

text:
Easy recipes and tastes JUST like the crepes my mom makes. This will be my go to crepes recipe from now on. AWESOME!  Only changes I made were to add 3 tablespoons of UNSALTED butter instead of 2. It was nice an buttery flavored without taking away the texture of the crepes. I also put the liquids in one bowl while putting the flour in the other and slowly adding the liquid while whisking. I felt like it would have been too chunky adding the eggs to the flour. Turned out AMAZING!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was perfect for our breakfast night.  We actually ended up doing it two nights in a row!  But we had to double the recipe to have enough for a full meal for four. I came from a pancake family, but my husband is a crepes kind of guy.  He specifically requested that I make crepes, and he was not disappointed with this recipe.  Neither was I, considering how quickly these cook up in comparison with pancakes!   When I had roughly a third of the batter left, I added a few tablespoons of white sugar and used those as dessert crepes.  We filled the normal ones with meat and cheese and topped with sour cream, and we filled the dessert crepes with either a mixture of cream cheese, confectioners sugar, and coolwhip and topped it with strawberries, or we spread butter and cinnamon/sugar over it before topping with a sweet cinnamon pear sauce, or we simply filled them with a custard pudding.  So delicious!  We will definitely be using this recipe again and again!

text:
I made crepes for Christmas breakfast and served rolled up with lingonberries. Tasty and lovely. The recipe was very easy, though I had to get the hang of swirling the batter in a frying pan. The first crepe I made was pretty pathetic. You have to swirl the batter quickly around the pan immediately after putting the 1/4 cup of batter in the hot frying pan. I used a frying pan that has curved sides, and this worked great.

text:
Very easy to prepare! I added tsp of Vanilla extract. Also it works with non-real butter. I suggest a medium heat or something not too high. I burned my first crepe and tossed it. I turned down the heat and they came out so perfect and became very simple to cook! I had it with bananas, banana syrup, and whip cream! Totally delicious, thin, delicate, and tastey! I would love to eat it with spinach and cheese too!!  Pour, flip, and serve. I got more of the batter in the fridge for a quick crepe any time. I totally recommend this recipe. :) Easy peasy!

text:
Thank you JENNYC819 and also to the other members that put in additional comments on this recipe.  I had to try this recipe last night and wow, they were as simple as can be to make and they really turned out great.  I took the advice of the other members and put the wet ingredients together first and then the dry... no lumps at all.  I didn't really want a sweet crepe as I am not a big sweet eater so I typed in "crepe fillings" on this site.  I went with the "Spinach, Mushroom and Bacon" filling but skipped on the "Warm Egg Sauce" that person suggested to put on top of these crepes and went with a simple topping of diced tomatoes with a hint of jalapenos for a zesty flavor to jazz it up a little.  They are absolutely great tasting.  We are eating like royalty over here.  Nice change of pace!  Thanks again.  Have a great day!

text:
I made these for breakfast this morning. It was easy and delicious. I did modify the recipe a bit - I used whole wheat flour instead of the all-purpose flour; 1 tsp. vanilla extract; 1 tsp. sugar & 1 T extra water. I mixed all the wet ingredients first then added the flour. I spread Nutella (chocolate hazelnut spread) on each of the crepes with sliced bananas & strawberries, rolled them up and put them in a non-stick skillet on low to keep warm. I plated them and dusted with powdered sugar. Thanks for the recipe.

Such a versatile recipe--it should be a staple in every household. I`ve found that adding a lot of sugar makes them hard to turn unless I add a lot of oil/butter, which I try to stay away from. I did, however, add 1-2 tbsp of ground flax seed to make it a healthy breakfast! Goes great with some whipped cream cheese or yogurt and some fruit! My boyfriend likes to take the richer route and add Nutella and banana slices--that would make for a great dessert!

text:
To make this a crepe style variation on the Chinese "scallion pancakes" I skipped the milk and used all water.  I also added minced green onion to the batter.  When done, cut into wedges and then dipped into equal parts soy sauce and vinegar. Done this way the scallion pancakes don't have to be kneaded and spiral-rolled so it is that much faster. It turned out quite good. Thanks!

text:
I really liked it, but I followed my own recipe the second time I tried this based on suggestions from other users and my own ideas. I added 1 cup of milk instead 1/2 milk and 1/2 water, I also added two tablespoons of sugar and vanilla extract because I wanted them to be sweet and 1 tsp of water. I also didn't like the egg texture so I reduced the recipe to one egg. They tasted sweet like a funnel cake and that's what I was going for!

First time making crepes and it worked out great!  I did have a hard time whisking out the lumps, so I put the batter into my cuisenart and it turned out smooth and creamy.  Good batter consistency for spreading it thin by manipulating the pan.  I highly recommend this recipe and am making these for my family's Christmas brunch. AWESOME recipe if you just do it right!!

text:
I put the wet ingredients in my blender then added the dry on top and blended till smooth. I just poured them right from the blender into pan and cooked. I spread plan Nutella on some and Nutella and sliced bananas on some and the rest I put peach preserves on. These came out great. I  have always seen Nutella in the grocery stores and never knew what to do with it. When we went to Italy this summer I realized Nutella is a staple in everyone's house over there. They sell it in LARGE jars like you could get at a Sams club. It is very rich so I spread it very thin on hot crepes.

I always use this recipe for crepes and the only thing I find I need to change is to add more liquid to thin the batter (I use real sea salt and real organic butter which really do give this a great flavor).  Also, I double the recipe adding the wet ingredients first to my blender, then adding the dry.  Used the Pumkin spice ricotta creme recipe (with sugar) as a filling for breakfast crepes for the kids.  Always a hit.  I guess I love it because it is so easy to make.

text:
I made this last night for in-laws over for dinner and they LOVED it! It was a smash hit. I used everything in th recipe except the salt. I added a little brown sugar and vanilla which made it all the better. I got those flour balls but I used my hands to squash them out before putting them on the griddle. Started in the center and used circular motions to pour the batter out until.. this helped keep them thin and helps with make a more rounded crepe.  I cut up bananas and strawberries, put them on the platter along side whip cream, confections sugar and melted chocolate. They all made their own crepe and it was quite delightful, very hands on and I received RAVE reviews!!! It was too good to stop and take a picture, but next time I will

text:
Simply fantastic!  This is such a versatile recipe ... you can fill it with anything.  My husband chose the savory route and added scrambled eggs.  I opted to go with orange marmalade!  The options are endless.  One thing I have read  is to allow the batter to sit in the refrigerator for an hour or so.  I tried this and the batter was a perfect consistency for making the crepes. I also used 1 cup of lowfat milk instead of 0.5 c milk and 0.5 c water.  It was still great.  Delicious!

text:
Wonderful and easy recipe.  The only modifications I made were to mix the water and milk in a measuring cup and alternate adding this with the flour.  If you add all the flour at the beginning it becomes an thick egg paste and it becomes clogged in the mixer blades.  I make this at least one or twice a week by rolling up the crepes and serving them with maple syrup.

text:
This crepe recipe is simple and a delight to make.  It tastes great on its own, but definitely needs to be served with a chunky topping -- these aren't just thin pancakes!  Try mixing in 1/2 teaspoon basil into the batter for every four servings made to make a Mediterranean crepe base, or fry with a spicy oil to make a hot tortilla wrap.  Jen's recipe has been utterly foolproof for me.

favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3868038.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been my go-to recipe for months.  Only variation for me is that I like to add some kind of extract for more flavor.  I've done vanilla, almond, and lemon so far.  Just a teaspoon or so and it really amps it up!  I've also added citrus zest, but it really depends on your filling and topping choice.

I'd also recommend a tiny pat of butter before pouring your batter.  I also use a small ladle to ensure the precise amount of batter per crepe.  Finally, I use a tortilla warmer to keep them hot until they're all done and ready.

Easy as can be.  I can't even make decent pancakes, but I dazzle people with what they think is  a really challenging gourmet breakfast.  (Ssssshhh, let's just make this our little secret...;))

None
text:
This is my go to for weekend breakfast.  I melt the butter in the non stick pan that I am going to use.  I mix all the wet ingredients together, then slowly whisk in the flour, then whisk in the melted butter.  I use measuring cup (1/3 or 80ml) to scoop the batter into the pan.  The first crepe will come out super buttery (and delicious!) All the rest come out fine.  You know it is time to flip when you shake the pan and the crepe moves freely.

text:
The thing with crepes is that you can't turn on the heat and then put the batter in. You have to let the pan get hot for a minute, so that it's like a burst of heat, and then pour the batter in. This will create the evenly cooked bottom so that your crepe will stay together.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is almost perfect. What's missing is the method: use a blender. You will find your crepes are lighter and more tender because the blender lets you quickly emulsify the batter with out toughening it. Use a nonstick pan, lightly buttered for each crepe. And most importantly, be purposeful and decided about moving the pan in firm, deft circles. Do it immediately and don't dither. Cover with a light towel, not paper.

text:
I'm in complete agreement with everyone else . . . mixing the flour and eggs together -- bad idea.  I was able to salvage the recipe in spite of the huge, heavy doughy lumps that initially formed and did not want to break down in the milk/water additions, but eventually it all worked out.  I will mix the eggs into the water/milk next time and then add to the flour.  All in all, very tasty crepes . . . light with just the right sponginess.  I served them with strawberry compote, whipped cream and a sprinkle of powdered sugar and cinnamon.  They were delish!  This recipe, with one minor modification, is definitely a keeper.

text:
Straight forward, easy, yummy! Can't get easier than this!
Mixed as per instructed sequence with handheld blender, beautiful smooth batter, no clumps! :)
I made mine with vanilla essence, pinch of sugar in batter to help crisping, spread thin on pan, brown/ crisp on one side. Sprinkled brown sugar, cinnamon, crushed almond flakes/ powder, unsweetened hershey choc powder while it's cooking/ crisping, before folding/ rolling over and serving.
Customization options for flavours endless depending on what one has at home! Cheese, ham, fruits, nuts, ice cream, etc.. Best ad hoc unplanned snack/ dessert ever!

This is a VERY EASY and successful recipe!  My usual recipe requires the batter to "rest" for an hour in the fridge and I didn't have time for that.  This one is ready immediately and cooked evenly and beautifully in the crepe pan.  It is also the FIRST time I didn't have to throw out the first crepe or two because the first one cooked so beautifully!  This will absolutely be my first choice crepe recipe from now on!  (I used the EXACT ingredients, but mixed all wet ingredients and salt first, then gradually added the flour last)  In the future, I will add sugar to the batter since I always make crepes for dessert and sweet ingredients.

text:
I just finished making these for my husband for a yummy Sunday morning breakfast that was easy and used ingredients we already had at home. They turned out delicious! We wanted sweet crepes, so I added sugar, vanilla extract and grated lemon and they were perfect!!! I definitely mixed all the wet ingredients together first and sifted in the dry ones instead of what the directions here state (mix the eggs into the flour). My brain automatically imagined a lumpy nightmare trying to do that! So I can't comment on those specific directions but I do know that my way worked and the batter was smooth and the crepes tasted heavenly!! I wish I had room to eat more! Excellent recipe, will make again definitely!

I want to try these with asparagus and a bit of hollandaise sauce next.  yum.  So many possibilities.

text:
Made it & loved it. Four small changes: 

1 - Added flour to liquid mixture as suggested by Morley. Sifted the flour to avoid clumps.
2 - Found the batter a bit too thick so I added about 1/3 cup of milk & water (1/6 cup of each). 
3 - I sprinkled maybe 1/4 tsp sugar as per suggestion by Christine Anderson, because I too prefer them a bit sweet. 
4 - Added 1/4 tsp vanilla extract. 

This is so much easier to make than I thought, will definitely make again.

I loved this recipe, it was quick and easy. However I made two changes: The order I mixed the ingredients and I added an ingredient. 
1)I mixed the milk and water together.

This prevents clumping, then I added the other ingredients.

Second I added a teaspoon of vanilla just to make them smell and taste a little nicer.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
My teenaged granddaughter pulled this recipe and proceeded to make it Christmas Eve.  She followed the instructions and the fun began.  It became to glob of goo.  She then tried the hand mixer and then the stand mixer.  The goo went right up the blades.  At that point, I saw what was happening and told her she had to add liquid and the goo immediately started behaving.  The "fluids first" process works much better for the less skilled and it produces wonderful crepes.  She enlisted the help of my teenage grandson.  Both are pretty good cooks for their age.  They had so much fun flipping the crepes.  We stacked them in the crockpot (for lack of anything else handy) with parchment between each, put them in the fridge and Christmas morning was quick and easy - no waiting for the crepes to be flipped!

userID:
11844820
Display Name:
Duckinabearsuit
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
GREAT RECIPE :) Just made crepes for the first time following this.

Some tips:  Make sure to add the wet ingredients to your bowl before mixing in the flour.  Sifting the flour is not always necessary in this case if you whisk the ingredients 'till its smooth.  

Nonstick spray (like Pam) works very well.  Butter leaves a more buttery taste, while nonstick spray doesn't.  

If you're feeling adventurous you can flip the crepe by picking up the pan and tilting it forward-then back quickly... No spatula needed!!

1/2 cup of batter makes bigger crepes unless you thin it out with a little more milk/water, then 1/4 cup will spread out to a large pan.

If you're wanting a more sweet breakfast/dessert style crepe, add cinnamon & powdered or granulated sugar to taste.

I've never made crepes before, but this recipe was so easy to follow that I may have to add it to my weekly menus :) They were so easy to make - pretty much just like making a really big, really thin pancake. I added 2 TB of sugar and 1 tsp of vanilla to the batter to make it a bit sweet. Other than that, I followed the recipe as is. Great basic crepes! I substituted a cholesterol free egg product for the eggs and they still turned out fabulous. Just like the real thing. I set up a crepe bar where the kids could choose their own toppings with savory and sweet options. Savory we went for mozzarella cheese, fresh basil, and tomatoes. Will be doing this again when kids come for a visit and more adult versions (thinking rum with the caramelized bananas) when they're not around.

Contrary to what the instructions say, DO NOT WHISK the flour and eggs together. Just let them sit in the bowl unmixed and then only, gradually add the milk while whisking. I just tried and it worked perfectly!

Display Name:
Springmix

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had been trying to make crepes for a year, but they always turned out a disaster, and I had sadly given up hope. But since I had run out of ideas of what to cook for dinner I thought I'd look up a recipe on-line and give it one more shot. I couldn't believe how easy it turned out to be with this recipe! I had bought a crepe pan for $7 and I was surprised to find out I didn't need to put oil or butter in the pan to flip them over. The secret is the butter in the batter. It melts and keeps the crepes from sticking to the bottom of the pan and it also makes them very easy to flip. We had them with the apple cinnamon mix one user recommended, with oranges and powdered sugar, and with my own filling, mushroom and feta cheese. You can also slice the remaining rolled up crepes in very thin strips and put them in chicken or vegetable broth for what the Germans call flaedle soup. Yum. Thank you very much from an enthusiastic and very satisfied crepe lover.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I agree with some other commenters that these are definitely NOT crepes in the traditional sense. Crepes should be thinner, more tender and have a bit of a chewy texture. These are more like thin, dry pancakes. Which was surprising given this recipe is very similar to Alton Brown's. To alter it I added a bit more milk, maybe 1/4 cup or so, and cooked each side for no longer than a minute. The batter will look very watery with the extra milk but it cooks fine so long as the pan is hot enough where water beads up and you use enough oil. While not 100% authentic these came out much closer to what a crepe should be.

text:
Mix the eggs & wet ingredients together, then sift in the flour and you will get ridiculously easy, "magically delicious" crepes. This was the first time I made them and, oh my goodness, they came out great. A 1/4 cup makes a small sized crepe. Tilt the pan right away since they start cooking immediately. I set my electric griddle at 325 degrees. Served these with Rhubarb Sauce II on this site. Outstanding.

text:
My family and I loved the taste.  Other than sifting the flour and adding it to the wet ingredients afterward (as user "Morley" suggested), I didn't do anything different with its preparation.  The sifted flour was so fluffy that it mixed immediately into the wet ingredients without any problems.

I didn't use any oil on the frying pan (since it was a non-stick pan) and the ingredients contained an oily substance- the butter- anyway, so the crepes did not stick whatsoever.

text:
Wish I would have read the other reviews before I made this.  The recipe calls for you to mix the flour and eggs together first.  This left me with a very lumpy batter.  I tried to smooth it out with a hand mixer but it did not work.  I would have thrown it out and started over but I used organic eggs and was not about to just dump them.  As others have mentioned mix wet ingredients together then add dry.

Super easy to make, even for a novice like me. I used a cast iron skillet and they turned out perfect! I wanted to make blintzes, but I didn't have all ingredients on hand for the filling, so I mixed what I had left of the tub of whipped cream cheese, a little sugar, vanilla and a splash of milk (sorry, I didn't measure).. whisked that together  (right in the cream cheese container), made blintzes out of the mixture and the yummy crepes, and topped them off with frozen berries that I had heated in the microwave to make a sauce. Sooooo good.

text:
At first  I thought strange to do flour and eggs first but it worked just fine for me. Pour liquid in slowly - I used a cup of coconut milk. Turned out better than another recipe I tried. My son thought these were awesome...with chocolate peanut butter. I had mine with powdered sugar and papaya. The thickness allowed for picking them up with the PB filling. Tried some with a squirt of Nestle Choc syrup in the batter before cooking - a little sweetness and my son says they are even better with PB! Had some for di her and freeze the left with wax paper I betwixt in a plastic baggie. Just heat and serve, no thawing required.

text:
Simple and excellent recipe.  I made 1/2 the batch into breakfast with scrambled eggs, mushrooms and Asian marinated chicken. The other 1/2 into sweetened crepes with ~1/8 cup each of granulated and powdered sugar.  Made a mango filling by chopping up 2 into small bits and cooking it with about 1 T butter, 1 T sugar, and 1/4 t each of cinnamon and nutmeg.  Served with powdered sugar on top.  Both were delicious.

text:
Two tips I learned in France: 
1. Let the batter sit for at least an hour.  This helps the flour to better absorb the butter, and makes everything much smoother.
2. Add a couple tablespoons of Calvados.  Completely optional, but makes the consistency and flavor really nice.

Great recipe-simple and always a crowd-pleaser!

text:
These were good for savory crepes, but I wouldn't say amazing.  I did, however, make the mistake of trying to cool down the melted butter by adding the milk to it...what I was thinking, I have no idea, because it curdled the milk a tad (stupid!).  In the end, it all worked fine, but that definitely wasn't ideal.  We made savory cuban crepes...pulled pork, ham, pickles, cheddar, mustard and hot sauce.  So good!  We also tried to add some sugar and vanilla to the second half for some sweeter crepes, but next time I would just use a sweeter recipe (I've head the Vanilla Crepes recipe is awesome).

text:
These are great as is. I always triple the recipe though for my family of 7. Usually I use half milk and half chocolate almond milk, or all milk for a richer taste. If using milk, I add a couple dollops of honey to sweeten. I also use all or half/half whole wheat flour and white flour. It tastes just as good with whole wheat. I keep a plate in a warm oven and stack them as I make them to keep them warm. Serve with fresh diced strawberries and toasted pecans and whipped cream. Not the most healthy breakfast, but on occasion, we look forward to this!

text:
I halved this recipe to try. Used vegetable oil to replace butter so it is healthier. Fried the first half of batter as original recipe. Original recipe is easy, quick and yummy.   Then I added 3 Tbsp cocoa powder and 2 Tbsp sugar to the 2nd half of batter (about the amount of cocoa+sugar I would add to the same amount of water (batter) when I make cocoa drink so I think u could adjust according to diff brands/sweeten/non-sweeten etc), fried it and become chocolate crepe! Personally I like the chocolate crepe better ( I like sweets :D). Guess kids will like it and good as dessert too :).
