text:
Wow! These were UNBELIEVABLE!! I have never attempted crepes before as they intimidated me. I had no idea they were so easy. I followed the suggestion of a couple reviewers to add a bit of sugar as well as a splash of vanilla. I mixed the wet ingredients first, then added the dry and gave the mix a quick whirl with my electric whisk. A good non-stick pan is necessary. I didn't need to butter it beyond my first crepe. This is the perfect recipe to add versatility to the usual family brunch breakfast choice in our house, pancakes or waffles or eggs. I can't wait to make it again and experiment with fillings. Thank you SO much for sharing!

text:
I love this recipie as it got me making crepes again, even without a crepe maker, I just use my large shallow non-stick skillet.  As I was making my Saturday morning mocha I got a inspiratation for a varient, that turned out well.  I made this with a half recipie, but I'll list the quanities generically. These have got a pretty chocolate color and subtle chocolate taste, but I may adjust the quanities later.   -Replace the water with coffee (cooled to Room Temp) - Replace about a forth of the flour with hot chocolate mix  - Add a little bit of vanilla extract  (maybe 1/4 tsp for a full recipie) Mix & cook as normal.  I enjoyed them plain but I could see these becoming dessert soon.

text:
Strongly recommend that you thin your batter unless you like a heavy crepe for breakfast; or, if you decide on a dessert crepe, fold with sour cream inside, spoon on fruit, or syrup, etc.  For dinner, use the un-thinned original recipe: because they are not sweet you can bulk up most meals with these crepes, even when you have curry, stew, or soup.

text:
I love this recipe! I whisk all the wet ingredients first then slowly whisk them into the dry ingredients. I usually double the recipe as they disappear fast. I like to make them ahead of time and keep them warm inside a folded dish towel. I have even made them the morning before a dinner party. I wrap them in the towel then clingwrap over the top. Put them in the fridge until ready to serve. A minute or 2 in the microwave and they're ready to go. I serve them with starwberries, nutella & whipped cream, or my son's favorite.. a sprinkling of sugar & cinnamon. YUM!

Perfect recipe.  Made nice, smooth crepes.  If you want them a little rougher looking use about a tsp of oil each time.  I usually turn by hand after hitting the side of the stainless steel pan.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-07-18T11:14:20.183
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1207712
Display Name:
Ashley_Belle
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
45
favoritesCount:
180
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/358200.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always thought that crepes were one of those things that you could never make at home as good as restaurants, but boy was I wrong... and these are actually better! I picked this recipe because I liked that you didn't have to sift anything and the batter didn't have to sit at all. If you're having a little bit of trouble with the eggs and flour like I did, just start adding the milk and it will mix up just fine. I added 1 tsp vanilla and 1/4 cup sugar to the batter to make these a little sweeter. I use 1/2 cup to put it in the pan vs. the 1/4 cup it calls for, and I made sure use a little butter in the pan before every crepe. As soon as I flip the crepe, I put the filling on so it can heat up a little (we use cottage cheese and fruit)... you just gotta be careful not to spill it when taking the crepe out of the pan.  Top with a little powdered sugar, whip cream (canned), and strawberry syrup, and you have an amazingly good breakfast!

text:
Great crepe batter for dinner / savory crepes.  Made chicken and spinach crepes with this recipe, with no changes except to let the batter rest 1 hour before cooking (gets a better consistency and smoothness of flavor).  I do not recommend it for dessert crepes because it is too thick.  Use "dessert crepes" by ANN57 which are the perfect runny consistency for dessert crepes.

text:
I made them GLUTEN-FREE! and they were fabulous!  This was my first attempt at crepes and I had NO trouble at all!  For the all-purpose flour I used ONE CUP of a gluten-free all-purpose mixture (2 cups white rice flour, 2/3 cup potato starch - NOT potato flour, 1/3 cup tapioca, 3/4 tsp. xanthan gum).  It made 10 8" crepes that my picky children and my husband gobbled up!  Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We have a couple of people in our family that cannot have wheat gluten, and this recipe converted easily and deliciously!  I substitute a gluten-free flour mix (in my case Bette Hagman's Featherlight) plus 1/4 tsp xantham gum. I think that any gluten-free mix would work.  Additionally, the gluten-free crepes hold up well, which isn't always the case with GF. I now make up a huge batch and store them in the fridge to use for lunches and breakfasts during the week, PBJ, Nutella, Ham & Cheese, Burritos -- so easy and so satisfying!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/148672.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent and simple. I used white whole wheat flour instead of all-purpose. Beat the eggs and milk well before adding into the dry ingredients. Don't overmix! Mix just enough to destroy clumps or you'll get tough crepes. However, it's really hard to screw up this recipe unless you let the crepes totally burn. These crepes with berries and chocolate syrup are great to surprise someone you love in the morning.

text:
I agree with one of the previous posters, when they said that sifting in the flour works better.  If you don't the batter tends to be very lumpy, because it's difficult to whisk in the eggs.  

You should try making them and when you flip them to cook the other side, add a deli slice or two each of Swiss Cheese and Black Forest Ham.  Fold into halves or quarters, and enjoy!

text:
I decided to use this recipe to make a delicious dinner for some houseguests, and boy did they enjoy it. First I prepared a box of good ol Kraft mac & cheese and a 24-oz ribeye from Wal-Mart (you know they sell those there now, just marvelous) and fried it up with some lawrys and some of my special seasonings. Then I just chopped up the steak to tiny bits and mixed it up with the mac. Then I made up the crepes just like the recipe says accept I had to add some more milk because they were pretty thick. And once I'd done that made some delicious mac and cheese and steak crepes! Really one of a kind and really wowed my dinner guests all to town. They are sure to tell there friends just like I'm telling you folks. 5 stars!

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious, not intimidating!  
I, like others, found it works best to mix the egg with the wet ingredients rather than alone with the flour.  When I mixed them alone with the flour the batter and the finished product were lumpy.  
I found the most success - soft, foldable crepes - when I put a little butter in the pan before each one, or sometimes every third one.  This is using Rachael Ray non-stick cookware which it will not stick to w/o butter, but w/o the butter they were sometimes hard and brittle.

5

text:
Extrememly easy to make - and I usually burn things like this.
The batter was very lumpy at first.  I had to give it a lot of elbow grease to get it thinned out (don't have a mixer.)
I upped the recipe for 8 crepes (but it made 10 smaller ones.)  Used the sugar and vanilla extract like others had said.
These were somewhat rubbery.  Next time I will try putting them in the fridge like others suggested.
Will experiment with this one again and see if I can get the texture right.

text:
A very good recipe. Used this with cinnamon, blackberry preserves, and nutella because that was what I had on hand. Due to another review, I used about 75% of a 1/2 cu. measuring cup for each crepe. Also made one savory crepe using just melted cheese which was equally tasty.

Tip: use a large spatula and once it's under the crepe a bit, shake the pan to coax the crepe unto the spatula solidly enough to flip it without tearing. When you're ready to put it on a plate, simply invert the pan quickly above the plate so it falls right off--perfectly shaped and never torn.

text:
When I was a little girl, my grandfather made the best crepes around.  He passed before sharing his recipe.  This one is almost an exact replica of it, minus the love that was put into it.  I have made this recipe for breakfast the past 3 mornings.  SO SIMPLE and easy to make.  Great filled with different jellys or sour cream topped with fruit and powdered sugar.  I added cinnamon to the mixture instead of sugar for an added taste.

text:
So easy and simple.  We fill them with a mixture of cottage cheese, cream cheese and a little sugar.  You can also use orange marmalade or just plain butter.  Add 1/2 tsp vanilla and 1 TBS sugar to the crepe batter for sweet fillings.  They are fantastic!

text:
Although I've never made crepes before, this recipe was easy easy easy.  I blended the ingredients in a blender, making the batter very smooth.  I used a fairly new 8" nonstick skillet coated with butter.  Instead of using a spatula to turn them, I flipped them like I would an egg over easy.  Every single crepe turned out perfect.  I filled them with a variety of things and my family, even my young kids, gobbled them up.

text:
This recipe is definately a winner! After visiting Europe and eating their wonderful crepes, I wanted to learn how to make my own. This was my first try, and they came out just perfect. My mom tried them and said I should become a professional chef after. Here are the only adjustments I made: a bit of vanilla and splenda to make them sweeter, and a bit extra water and milk because I wanted them thinner. They were good enough to eat plain, but even better with whipped cream, vanilla pudding and cinnamon sprinkled on top. I can't wait to try new variations.

text:
Very good crepes! I used my blender to combine the ingredients. I forgot to add the butter to the mixture, but alternated butter and coconut oil spray for each of the crepes. I wanted them on the sweeter side, so I added a few tblsp of  powdered sugar and one tsp of vanilla. I enjoyed three of these for dinner tonight on Shrove Tuesday, with tomorrow, Ash Wednesday, being the start of Lent. I filled them with a mixture of cottage cheese, cream cheese and powdered sugar and had with a little maple syrup.  I also like a reviewer's suggestion of filling the crepes with sauteed finely chopped apples, butter, sugar, cinnamon and nutmeg which could be for breakfast. Thanks for the recipe!

userID:
5820552
Display Name:
BristalK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0

5
favoritesCount:
19
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Crepes have never come out as perfect for me before as these did today! I thought it seemed unusual to blend the egg and flour first, and after reading a review saying their attempt to go in that order resulted in lumpy batter, I decided to blend differently. First, I whisked the egg, milk, and water. Added the salt and a touch of orange blossom water for the thrill of it. Whisked in the flour until mostly smooth. I added the melted butter last so the cold of the milk/egg mixture Wouldn’t solidify the butter before it had a chance to blend in... maybe overthinking it, but It worked out great.  I cooked them in an 8” pan that I wiped a very thin layer of canola oil in and But if butter. Scooped the batter with 1/4 measuring cup, but thought it needed just another 1/8 cup more. They looked beautiful, tasted great, and had a wonderful texture. Saved this recipe  to my favorites for future use.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-11-09T07:50:04.227

Display Name:
Rob S Yourhouse
isPro:

0

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7005152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great crepes, turned out really delicious!  I ended up multiplying the recipe by 6.

The only issue I had was mixing the eggs with the flour was very difficult, and once done, mixing the milk and water in afterwards was even harder.  So much so I had to use a electric wand mixer to get it all consistent.  For anyone trying this I’d suggest mixing the eggs flour AND water altogether at once rather than just the eggs and flour.  Then add the milk after.  Otherwise you’re in for a very sore wrist.  Other than that the crepes turned out great and are better than any variation I’ve made before.
Review:

Super simple. When I follow the directions for mixing I always end up with small lumps because the egg and flour mixture doesn’t mix well into the other ingredients. I recommend adding the milk to the eggs and flour before mixing the first time to avoid this.

country:

text:
I had forgotten the recipe I used to use so I started with this one. I should have read all the way through first. I guess most people do not own a traditional crepe pan ( the pan is convex and you need your batter to be thin and in a pie pan.)You heat and lightly butter the crepe pan using a paper towel, invert the hot pan and dip quickly into the batter.  Cook for about 90 seconds should easily peel off with the edge of a fork and your fingers pulling off the crepe. This batter recipe is way too thick to do this with, I fixed it by using the nordic ware website. It uses 3 time the milk only 6 tablespoons of water and adds another egg. It it designed for the proper crepe pan. I added a photo of my crepe pan.

I made these using unsweetened almond milk and vegan butter instead of the regular choices for those two ingredients and they were great! Only thing I have to say about it is, the batter was slightly thick for a crepe recipe. I found mixing the wet ingredients all together then sifting the flour in worked much better than the recipe said which was the other way around. Going to try it a little adjusted next time for a smoother batter!

text:
Excellent recipe. The key is whisking consistently and making sure the butter is melted properly. The eggs and flour do lump up but the moment you start to mix the milk water and then the butter it gets very smooth. Whisk briskly until smooth. Made this and sunny side up eggs and a glass of Prosecco for my husband and I. Best breakfast ever.

This was by far the worst crepe recipe I've ever followed. They were edible, sure, but absolutely the smelliest, most sticky, difficult to make crepes I've ever attempted. Honestly, like I'm not even exaggerating I actually hated them, and it usually takes a lot for me to hate a crepe recipe. The ingredients are right but the recipe as written does not result in good crepes. By mixing the eggs and flour first this ends up with a very lumpy batter. Crepe batter should be thin and smooth.

 If you are making this recipe mix the wet and dry separately then combine.

text:
EASY! We made this in juvenile detention for a cooking project. For a change up- we used organic food coloring and divided the recipe so that  the crepes came out with bright, beautiful colors. We mixed some cream cheese with lemon and sugar. We also cooked blueberries sweetened them with sugar, added some lemon juice and thickened them with cornstarch. Last, we made the Southern Fried Apples with frozen apples from my apple tree.  To assemble, 3 dolapes cream cheese, a spoon of blueberries, then roll the crepe, drizzle a little more blueberry and a side of apples --- This project was a HIT!

text:
Sooo, I doubled the recipe so we could enjoy more crepes and they taste really great, only problem we had was they were kind of fat for crepes, maybe it was how hot I had the skillet. Also realized halfway in that I’d forgotten the butter. Once I turned it down and added butter they turned out perfect.

I also tried with choco chips in the batter near the end just for curiosity sake. So good!

Update: made them the second time from start to finish and they were almost perfect crepe texture. Just didn’t follow mixing instructions so i assume it does help something with texture more than I thought.

text:
great recipe! in order to prevent the lumpiness that people see (including myself), you must do the following. Melt butter fully and set aside. Add the flour, eggs and milk/water first and fully mix. Pour butter a little at a time into mix, mixing vigorously.

text:
First attempt to make crepes.  I am aware that some purists say you need a crepe pan but since I don't own one I used a skillet.  Per some various comments, and that they are essentially thin pancakes,  I added zest of one orange,  juice from one orange,  and omitted the salt during to dietary restrictions. I then topped them with some unsalted butter and dusted on some confectioners sugar.  They turned out very well and I think I like them better than pancakes in a way. Other than the 3 ingredient additions I prepared the batter as the recipe is written.  Considering it was my first time making crepes and not having the crepe pan. I think these turned out pretty good,  pics sent.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5371495.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Much like all the rest, I whisked together the wet ingredients together FIRST before adding in the flour. I also sifted the flour a little bit at a time to make sure there was no lumps (and also because as someone with Carpal Tunnel, whisking all that flour together would’ve hurt a lot). I also added about a 1/4 teaspoon of Vanilla Extract to help boost the flavour a little bit. Small tip for the newbies to crepes: Wait until the edges of the crepe starts to curl up before flipping it for the first time. If you absolutely have to grease your pan, do so gently so you don’t mess up the batter. :)

text:
I just use a hand mixer to incorporate all of the ingredients.  These aren't like pancakes where you can over-stir the ingredients.  You actually want the batter to be really smooth and runny.  So ignore the instructions and just through everything in the bowl and blend together.  They turn out great and the kids love them for a special breakfast.

text:
I usually make these more on the sweet side and double the recipe by adding an additional 1/4 cup of sugar and a teaspoon of vanilla.  Also use a 1/4 cup of batter when using a 10" pan.  I'm sure that you can use a little less but this seems to coat the bottom of the pan the best.

None
text:
For the basic recipe, this is alright. Add the dry ingredients slowly, not the wet. This will result in a better consistency to your batter.

I added a tsp of Vanilla extract.

Also, this is not in the directions, but the secret to making crepes that don’t tear is letting the batter rest an hour before putting them in your pan. This allows the bubbles to settle so that there aren’t “weak spots” in your crepes

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
They take some practice to get them coming out of the pan not looking like scrambled eggs, but once you have it down, they're pretty good. I had to add some salt and sugar to the batter. I quadrupled the recipe (by accident… I meant to double it) and it was the perfect amount to feed my family plus some extras for the next day. OVERALL, it's a good recipe if you have made these before, and make sure to double it for 2-4 people and quadruple it for 5 or more people. 
SUGGESTIONS: 
- add a few large pinches of sugar to the batter
- do not put oil in the pan
SUGGESTIONS FOR TOPPINGS:
- goat cheese or feta (or flavored like Boursin(R) ) with veggies like spinach, tomato, and cucumbers
- white cheddar cheese with spinach and other veggies
- dessert crepe with whipped cream and honey
- dessert crepe with hazelnut chocolate spread

userID:
8581195
Display Name:
angelinamarie3
isPro:
False

11

83
favoritesCount:
1642
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5239802.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not a bad recipe at all! Very simple, and common ingredients most have on hand. Like most crepes- the first to cook is always the “practice pancake”... best to discard, as the rest cook properly & the light, soft texture they should be. I actually did 2 batches, as I found one batch makes about 8 medium crepes, total. The second batch came out WAY better than the first, because of the pan being hot & well seasoned at that point. But, 8 medium crepes is not bad at all for the minimal amount of ingredients! 

My only complaint is that I had a difficult time keeping “lumps” out of the batter. Definitely had to stir it constantly between pouring it into the pan, and even then, I had several that came out with some penny-size chunks in them. So, I don’t really know how to keep that from happening- maybe using a whisk to stir instead of a spoon? 

Overall, these were really easy, fairly quick to make & I am happy with the result. They tasted great, even plain! I topped mine with strawberries, a little chocolate drizzle & whipped cream, but there are really a TON of ways you can stuff or top crepes, depending on the meal! Will definitel keep this recipe & continue trying to perfect it.
Review:
Rating:
5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe! It was the first time I've made crepes. I think freshly made, these are an absolutely delicious eggy treat, but a bit on the oily/buttery side when you hold them in your hand. perhaps that cannot be avoided. No need to oil your pan. Also, when made ahead of time and left in the fridge, if you don't microwave them, they are a bit hard/rubbery. Microwaving will do the trick to revitalize them to perfection, but if you fill them with whipped cream like I did, that will leave you a delicious runny mess! haha. But they are really good, the husband cannot get enough. Will make again.

This is a very good recipe! I wouldn’t change anything, unless you make the batter the night before you cook the crepes.  I made the batter on a Sunday night for breakfast Monday morning. text:
Delish!! Perfect crepes. I mixed my dry and wet separately first. I added the flour little by little to all the wet ingredients. Added 1 tsp vanilla to the batter. I also used my KitchenAid hand mixer. I put some powdered sugar in too. I would say three tablespoons worth. I don’t have a crepe maker so I used my rectangular, electric nonstick skillet and it worked perfectly. For filling I used non-fat greek yogurt with powdered sugar and vanilla. Yum!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5491097.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! Very simple, very delicious. I don't know why the instructions say whisk the eggs and flour first; that results in a sticky dough you then have to liquify with the water and milk. Just beat everything together at once (sans the butter and salt). 

Also, I recommend spreading the batter out with a spatula as soon as it hits the pan. The batter cooks incredibly fast so you might end up with a very lopsided crepe if you try spreading it by tilting the pan.

MADE THEM GLUTEN FREE mine gluten free, with “Namaste foods for everyone, gluten free perfect flour blend.”Initially following the recipe with this cup for cup flour, made them too thick.  To ensure consistency I recommend mixing all ingredients separately, then slowly sift GF flour into liquid mix until right consistency.  Should be extremely thin, able to easily spread out onto your cooking pan.

text:
Great recipe. Thank you. I have found the method of mixing the cloud and the by does work as long as you are willing to spend more time whisking everything when you are the wet ingredients. If you want to spend less time on this recipe, first mix dry and then all went in separate bowl and mad a well in the cloud and whisk everything together. And make sure your own is not enough before you put the first crepe on. I find the first is the hardest and they all cook consistently after that.

text:
I am 100% satisfied with the result. Made half of recipe.  The crepes came out tender and tasty, and I will use this recipe from now on. The 4 stars rather than 5 is because 1. Mixing eggs and flour doesnt work for me, i used the usual method of mixing all liquids then adding flour, and 2. The key to tender tasty result is having all ingredients at room temp, to start, then letting the batter  stand at toom temp at least 1 h. before cooking. I feel a well written recipe should contain all of the important points, rather than taking chances.
Also, the batter may be kept in fridge overnight, but before frying bring it to room temp, which may take 2 hours.

text:
Great recipe! My changes:  1) I used almond milk instead of the milk/water, and found that I needed to add roughly a 1/4 cup more so the batter would spread evenly around my crepe pan. 2) Also used 1 tbs sugar. 3) I combined all wet ingredients first, sifted the dry, then added the wet to dry as I would have cake batter and whisked, then rested for 30 mins - mixing the eggs/flour together to start with struck me as strange. Will make again :)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2527208.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these savory with cheese, caramelised shallots and olives. After flipping the crepe I piled on the filing, folded it in half,  cooked on both sides to melt the cheese. Yummy!

For the batter  I used 1 cup of milk, no water.  I sift the flour in a bowl, make a hole in the middle and crack the eggs in. Start whisking in the hole adding milk slowly drawing in small amounts of flour at a time. Perfect consistency every time. Make sure you are using a non stick pan and it's very hot. You only need a little butter in the pan, or it curdles  the batter and you want it sizzling hot. I only added butter to the pan for every other crepe.

text:
In response to BABYGIRL30S:
Let the crepe cook longer before trying to flip it. It seems like forever for such a thin amount of food. The edges will pull away from the pan when it is ready to be flipped. If your first is sticking, leave the second on longer, and so on. There should be very little/no scraping to get the crepe away from the pan. A super thin spatula helps too.  I hope you give this recipe another go! (I just realized she tried this recipe 11 years ago. I'm slow.)

text:
I can't even believe how good these are! Such simple ingredients, easy to prep, and the flavor was heavenly. I mixed all ingredients saving the flour, mixed them well to get a light fluffiness. I added a tbsp of sugar to mine. Then I mixed in the flour until the mixture was smooth. Having a good nonstick pan/griddle that heats evenly is key here. These crepes are French/German style so they cook up super fast. Shake the pan as soon as you see the edges lightly brown, flip them, and then don't wait long before you take them off the fire. They are truly perfect and I will definitely use this recipe again and again.

text:
I just finished making these crepes.  Mine came out wonderful with a few changes, mainly in the prep.  I whisked together the milk, water and eggs really well, added the cooled melted butter and again whisked well.  Then added the flour and salt.  Still whisking!  The batter should be lump free and pretty thin. After my first test crepe which was too thick, I added 2 tablespoons of water to the batter.  I used a full 1/4 cup measure in a 9 inch crepe pan, swirled well, and I had 8 nicely finished crepes.

text:
I make crepes for my family every new years morning and this is by far the easiest and tastiest recipe I've used. The ingredients are basic. I love the video. It gives great demo for first time crepe makers. I've given the site info to my adult sons who are making their own new years crepes this year. I had not thought of some of the non-dessert filling suggestions and plan to try them.  I did add about 2 T of sugar to our dessert crepes batter. Yum! I would use an electric mixer to prevent lumps  or add dry ingredients very gradually to wet ingredients if mixing by hand.

city:

country:
None
text:
Very nice and easy. 2nd time I made it though, I didn’t bother with trying to mix the flour with the egg before adding the milk. Instead I put all the ingredients except for the flour and butter  in the blender and added those 2 a bit at a time as the blender was going. Once all the ingredients were in there, I gave it all a good blast in the blender at high speed to make sure everything is well mixed. I find the crepes can be made thinner by using more milk or water than the recipe calls for. And by frying it in the frying pan I just flip them over in the air using the pan rather than messing around with a spatula. My daughter was able to do it the 2nd time she tried - she was so proud :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the advice of those who mixed liquids first and added dry ingredient second. After that, this recipe came out very nicely - the batter is thin enough to spread well into a very thin crepe. It also fries up nicely, loosening along its edges well to make flipping easier. Basic is an accurate description flavor-wise - if you want sweeter, you'd probably do need to add sugar etc. Savory crepes might also be embellished by herbs added to the batter. I focused on the filling rather than changing the batter. I added cheese slices and a stir fried mix of chicken, onions, garlic and spinach.  I doubled the recipe and made 4 savory, then 4 sweet crepes for dinner. The sweet ones we just filled with cut fruit, whipped cream and a drizzle of lemon curd. There was leftover batter, so I covered the mixing cup with plastic wrap and next day made 4 more.  I had to re-stir the mix a bit, but 2nd day crepes came out equally well.

text:
We added our usual additions to most breakfast recipes: cinnamon and pinch of salt to taste. Instead of 1/2 cup of water, we used apple juice. 
It was ridiculously good........some whipped cream topping with powdered sugar and I didn’t need any syrup. Perfect balance of light sweet crepes with a salted buttery flavor. my husband’s cooking standards are pretty high being he can cook me out of the kitchen any day and make anything amazingly well...and hours later he couldn’t stop remarking how delicious these crepes were. A new staple to our breakfast Saturdays!

NOTE: mix wet & dry ingredients separately! Also, feel free to add more melted butter to your recipe. It was a nice adjustment! Savory butter flavor to balance the apple juice.

text:
These crepes were so easy to make! I cooked these 1 min and 15 sec on each side, and they were light, fluffy, and golden brown. I was skeptical when I whisked the eggs with the flour, but the clumpy texture was soon gone after adding in the butter, milk, and water. I had to make these for a class project, and they were delicious! I recommend adding banana and raspberry jam for the finishing touches (maple syrup is also delicious!) Another note: I had enough batter for 6, but they were really tiny.

Display Name:
Olga_From_the_Volga

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall, a pretty good tasting recipe. However, DO NOT USE THE GIVEN METHOD! I have tried this recipe multiple times with the given recipe, and it always turned out the same: super thin, watery, liquid of milk and water with huge lumps of egg and flour clumps. Absolutely unusable. So I used the same ratios but with a different method. Combine the dry ingredients in one bowl, and add the milk and water to it and whisk together. Then add the eggs and combine, and then add the melted butter. This is the method my dad taught me and it has always worked. I also like my crepes sweet, so I added in 1 1/2 table spoons of sugar.
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
17632822
Display Name:
Paolo San Pedro
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
EASY! I didn't mix the ingredients in the suggested order but I did leave the proportions intact. I made 1/2 recipe by melting 1 tbsp butter in a large mixing bowl (in the microwave) and then adding 1/4 cup water and 1/4 cup milk to the warm melted butter to cool it down before mixing in one egg. Next I added a pinch of salt and 1/2 cup AP flour and mixed until smooth (makes 4 - 10 inch crepes). I filled mine with blueberries and goat cheese, but these crepes are so neutral in flavor that they could as easily be used for a savory dish rather than a sweet one. Very delicious and as easy as it gets ;)

text:
Easy peasy and tasty.. but the instructions?  I looked at them, knew it was really odd, but tried it anyway... yeah. dont  mix eggs and flour... this equals big lump. You can mix it out fine, but it is MUCH easier to mix liquids then add all at once to flour. I asked a couple of professional chefs if there could be any possible reason for  this to be mixed the original way?  Nope was the answer... I made my crepes savory... stuffed them with meatballs, marinara, cheese sauce and spinach.  YUM

text:
I've been making this every weekend for about 2 months now. 
I find mixing the eggs and water/milk first, then adding the salt and flour make the batter smoother. I add the butter last.
You need a nice hot pan to start...my first crepes didn't cook well until I learned to preheat my pan.
I also make sure I have a pre-measured portion of batter waiting for when I'm done a crepe and ready to make the next one...saves time and keeps my pan hot.
Kids love these! And so do I

text:
Amazing recipe.  To babygirl you asked what you did wrong and it was very clear from your review "well oiled pan"  when the recipe says lightly grease and they truly mean LIGHTLY.  To make these perfect you put some butter in the pan warm it and spread it around and then with a paper towel  wipe most of the butter out.  It is even better if you just use a brand new non stick pan with NO OIL Or  butter.   Making crapes is a technique more than a recipe.  I also agree all the wet ingredients should be mixed first and then the flour added but the base ingredients are perfect.

text:
Very easy to make and came out perfect on the 1st try. Soft and slightly crispy. I followed the same technique as others and prepared the wet ingredients first, but made a lil mistake by not melting the butter all the way, so when it was added to the other ingredients (still cold) it curdled up -- my fault. After adding the flour and all was still lumpy, I threw in the blender on low and it fixed the issue. That made the batter easy to pour into the hot pan, an added bonus. I also added vanilla and less than 1/4 cup of sugar for a sweet taste. My husband enjoyed this for Father's Day breakfast, served with sauteed apples and banana/nutella. Def a nice change v the same old pancakes or french toast. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Good basic recipe. The first time I made it, they came out great because I just skimmed over everything.. The second time, I followed the recipe EXACTLY and they came out pretty bad. Here's what I learned...skip whisking the eggs with the flour. And just do wet ingredients into dry ingredients, then whisk. And then also don't do medium-high heat. The highest heat you should use is medium.

text:
If you make it exactly as directed, you will have large lumps that are virtually unusable. The recipe should state that the milk, eggs and the butter should be at room temperature. Melting the butter and using cold milk, eggs and water will cause everything to seize up.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great! My family gobbled them up and I had to quickly whip up another batch which they also gobbled up. The only thing I would change is the technique, whisking the eggs and flour together just produces a gloppy blob that gets hung up inside the whisk.  When I made the second batch, I  whisked the eggs, liquids and flour together, adding the butter and salt last. You really need to get western with the whisk to break up all the flour clumps, though!  Next time I might just throw it all in a blender. We served ours with ham, mayo, even anchovies, which sounds crazy but is delicious.  For the sweet side, we did different combos of sliced strawberries, peaches, honey, and Nutella.

text:
Love using this recipe as I can never remember the quantities myself. I use 1cup of milk, just 1/2cup water and no butter. I prefer the way they come out (more like mums!) and I find it easier not having to worry about another ingredient.
I do whisk the flour and eggs first, but making sure it's mixed very well and then add in the wet ingredients very slowly. If you mix enough, the lumps will (usually) come out.

I love love crepes, especially when someone else makes them! Unfortunately my favorite crepe maker didn't have any combos I liked the other week when I had a major hankering for crepes. I finally decided to make my own, then decided we needed to make sure we had the best possible recipe. Over two days I tried three or four batter recipes, this was the favorite! We tried them with three fillings
 1. Baby spinach, sliced tomatoes and feta, 
2. Grilled kielbasa and sauerkraut,
3. Cream cheese, whipped cream and sugar filling with a cinnamon sugar drizzle. 
All three tasted amazing with this batter, no changes needed!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simple and delicious. A few critical adjustments make this batter much easier to whisk. Whisk all the wet ingredients and salt together. (I added sugar and vanilla.) Stir in the flour gradually. This is standard practice for pancakes and French toast. First the wet ingredients, then the flour or bread. Once the crepes were made, I added a cream cheese filling and blueberry syrup. So good!

(Note: By mixing the flour and eggs first, you create a rustic dough that then has to be transformed into a batter. It's very difficult to get all the lumps out.)

userID:
12948150
Display Name:
Brandy Searcy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
44
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1667821.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made a few changes:


1)  Used 1/2 c. sparkling water (I used a can of coconut flavored sparkling water because it's not pina colada season anymore, and I was tired of looking at it) instead of 1/2 c. water.  Added this to wet mixture and stirred with spoon instead of mixer.  
2)  Used 1 egg instead of 2 (I'm not a big fan of egg-y tasting cakes, crepes, or other sweet treats).  The carbonation from the sparkling water made up for the lack of the extra egg (I think you could substitute baking powder for the 2nd egg as well - I've seen egg-less recipes use 1 tsp. baking powder for 1 egg).
3)  Added 1-2Tbsp. sugar (added a little more sugar after the first batch).  Added the sugar to the wet ingredients and mixed.
4)  Mixed all wet ingredients first (beat 1 egg, then added milk, melted butter, and sugar and beat again).  Added 1/2 c. sparkling water and mixed with spoon.
5)  Added salt/flour mixture and mixed with spoon followed by beating with a mixer.
6)  Cooked in an iron skillet coated with a thin layer of butter.
7)  Served with the apple mix recommended by another reviewer (fry one finely cut apple in butter in a skillet adding ~1Tbsp. sugar.  Toss with cinnamon and nutmeg if desired - I added the rest of the can of sparkling water to the apple mixture while cooking to make a little more apple gravy).

userID:
17299975
Display Name:
Kendra
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3133405.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My go-to crepe recipe. Very quick, easy, and delicious. It's great for those times when you're just staring into your pantry with no idea what you want to eat. All the ingredients are right there, and you can adapt it for whatever craving you are having (sweet, savory, chocolatey, cheesy). My lazy fillings are jam and powdered sugar (sometimes I add Nutella) for sweet; Canadian bacon and cheddar cheese (and broccoli, if I have a Steamfresh bag in my freezer) for savory.

Side note: The first time I made these for my father-in-law he said they reminded him of the ones his [Dutch] mother used to make. My mother-in-law said she swore she saw tears in his eyes! :-D

text:
Great recipe. It doesn't matter in what order you mix the ingredients if you have a good blender. I use an immersion blender for both crepes and Dutch pancakes and never have lumps. The only modification I make to this is that I add about 3Tbs of sugar for sweet crepes. Leave it out for savory. Consistency is perfect and these are super easy!

LOSTCOOKINSWITZERLAND
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/190014.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've seen a few reviews concerning lumps. Something you need to know about making crepes. First, use a whisk to incorporate the ingredients. When you mix the eggs and flour it will be lumpy.  I've found the best way is to only add a bit of the flour to the eggs and whisk them. Then alternate the liquid and flour, whisking until smooth. Second...make it the day before, cover the batter and refrigerate. This allows the batter to settle and get the bubbles out. Then, when ready to cook, give a quick stir and pour the batter about a 1/4 of a cup at a time onto your pan that's been heated over medium/high. Tilt the pan to spread out the batter and cook until golden brown, flip and cook the other side. Place on plate, serve with fruit, jam, etc. and enjoy!

Sifting the dry ingredients into the wet is generally much easier than the other way around, and that really helped here.

freakacook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3960842.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy to follow recipe with satisfactory results. I took someone's advice and added the flour last, after mixing the wet ingredients. No lumps at all. I also added a little extra flour because the dough was a tad runny. The dough will make 2 large crepes or 4 smaller ones. The directions said 'medium high' heat. Every stove I've ever used has numbers on the dials, and 'medium high' could mean different things. I cooked my crepes on about '4' and they turned out fine. Anything higher than that, and they got too hot. Also, don't forget to re-grease your pan inbetween crepes so they don't stick (unless you have a non-stick pan; I do, but I still grease it just in case.) Overall, very pleased with the results. Will definitely cook them again in the future.

Add: I have only made this recipe once, but every time I refresh the page it will say 'You did it!' and adds another time I 'made it'. I click undo, but it doesn't undo it. It now says I've made this several times, which is an error.

text:
I have made this recipe as written (whisking eggs with flour) and my own way (whisking eggs with milk, then adding sifted flour). As written the batter was horrible - the eggs and flour turned into a doughy paste and after adding milk and water it thinned but I couldn't get the lumps out. I whisked for several minutes and eventually dumped it and started over. I therefore can't review on taste for this recipe based on the instructions.

I have made this several times my way, however, with excellent results - smooth batter and all. 

I like this recipe and I make it often. I strongly recommend  whisking the eggs and milk together prior to adding (sifted) flour. I gave this three stars because it's great when directions are tweaked but not as written.

text:
Wow!   That's all I can say.  I followed the recipe exactly, and these crepes were perfect.  They tasted like the crepes we had all over France, and they were so simple to make.  I had always been afraid to make crepes, thinking they were too finicky, but this recipe proved that anyone can make delicious crepes.  I filled some with Nutella, some with lemon curd, and some with fresh gooseberries.  They all received a light dusting of confectioner's sugar, and they were all happily consumed by young and old.  Thank you for a wonderful recipe!!

Super easy and effective. I used this recipe to learn how to make crepes and have since only every used this recipe. I make this about twice a month on Sundays. I add a little vanilla to the batter if we'll be having them sweet. For savory you can leave plain or add some herbs. I really recommend this recipe! text:
I used only ¼  cup of water because the batter didn’t seem very thick after adding the milk (will be good to exercise your own judgement here). 

Because I was using a manual whisk, i was unable to achieve 100% smooth texture for my batter, although it looked homogenous on the surface. I had to transfer the batter into another bowl, through a sift, to seperate the lumps which were sunken at the bottom of the batter.

Overall the recipe's great and I am really satisfied with the crepes i made this morning : )

text:
Great basic recipe! If people are finding the batter lumpy by following the instructions, what I do is whisk the eggs, butter and salt first, and then add the flour and milk in alternating steps a few tablespoons at a time. That way it also helps to gauge how thick you prefer the crepe batter.

I signed up specifically to review this. Do not mix the flour and eggs in the beginning. Add all ingredients then mix. I didn't do it but I know mixing just eggs and flour makes noodles. Also I added a tiny bit more milk as well as a handful of sugar and a cap of vanilla just because I thought it would taste better. Turned out perfect! Good base recipe but needs a little embellishment

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3594845.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect recipe, the best I have ever found.  When it says to mix in the wet ingredients, be sure to form a small well in the middle of the dry ingredients with your fist and fingers, then gently place the egg and milk inside the well.  Then, place the head of your mixer into the well and start blending from the inside out!  That prevents lumps and also the pain of sifting in flower like other people suggested.  Also, for the person who said it turned into scrambled eggs, do not scramble the crepe!  Just let it be and it will turn into what you want it to in two to four mins.

text:
This is a great basic recipe but I made a lot of changes. 
I also ran into the problem of  clumps of flour. Instead of mixing the flour with the eggs I beat my eggs and then alternate adding a bit of milk and a bit of flour. I also don't like using half water half milk so I add just a cup of milk. When making a dessert crepe I also use sugar instead of salt. I've made these for my french class and for my family and every time they are a hit.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these two different ways now, Once i used rice milk one cup of it and coconut butter two table spoons of it and added one table spoon of cinnamon these were for my mom who cant have milk or butter and everyone ate them up and loved them, the second time i made them i added a cup of milk "cows milk"  (no water each time) and the same ratios for the rest with real butter  and i used a food processor to blend the wet first and then slowly added the dry. I did add three teaspoons of vanilla extract it made it have a delicious perfumed smell when cooking. I put nuttella and bananas nuttella and raspberry and sweet cream cheese and a mix berry jam in BOTH kinds and they were a hit with the family! ( everyone is very very picky)  

MY recommendations: add all milk and not water and keeping the rest the same and MIX THE WET STUFF FIRST SLOWLY ADD THE POWDER SO IT DOESNT GET CLUMPY 
and enjoy!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4569544.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is good all I would recommend is to mix wet ingredients first in a blender, then add the flour, blend it again until mixed, and then add the butter last. Let it set for 5 minutes. This will save you from a lumpy batter. Pour it with a measuring cup (1/4 cup at a time). The recipe will yield exactly 8. Just practice a bit. Make sure your pan is hot. Sprinkle some water drops if they sizzle your pan is ready for making them!

text:
Will definitely make again and again. 
Adjustments: I kept the ingredients as is but changed method. I put all ingredients into my bullet, whizzed and let stand at room temperature for 10 mins while I prepared the filling. I dolled this method as per Martha Stewart recipe (her ingredients/measures were different). Turned out light, no lumps, not eggy and delicious. I like that there is no sugar in recipe and you can add it when done, if necessary.

This recipe has all the ingredients right, but the technique is wrong. Combine the eggs, milk and water. Add the cooled, melted butter. Sift in the flour and salt while whisking.  Once the batter is smooth it is ready to cook.

These were easy and great.  You can add sugar or anything else you want them for dessert purposes.  For all those that said their batter was lumpy... that is your error.  Go slowly and follow directions.  Also, I read from someone that you do not combine eggs and flour together in that order.  Well, if she really knew how to cook/bake she would know that you absolutely do in certain recipes, such as this. I will not give a lesson on baking here.. but the reason for this method is easily googled.

text:
I made them for breakfast today and they are very good.   I made the crepes one by one and stacked them between wax paper.  Then I filled each one with a TBS of softened Cream Cheese and some Homemade Blueberry filling (Frozen Blueberries, Splenda, CornStarch)  Yum.  Served them with a small tsp of Sour Cream on each one.  If I made them again I would definitely measure each crepe in stead of just pouring the batter into the skillet.  It looks easy but measure.  Also I did what other posters said and added the dry to the wet and was successful in no lumps.    I used a spray on the pan for the first one.  I think using butter would make a browner, crisper crepe.  Good, Easy recipe.

I always use this recipe - it's good for the quantities. However, do not follow the instructions. Mix milk, water, and beaten egg first, then whisk in flour. Otherwise, as Morley has pointed out, it will be exceptionally lumpy and almost unsalvageable.

text:
The one change I make to this recipe is with the water. Instead of using 1/2cup water I use a 1/4cup water and 1/4cup orange juice.  We fill with sweet cream..sour cream, whipped cream cheese and powder sugar to sweeten. Strawberries on top and whip cream. 
I also learned to use 1/2 a soup ladle into the pan. You want these thin because you don't turn them. Slide out of pan when top has a firm look.

I normally make a huge batch and the battereyg stays together really well, just make sure to whisk it a bunch because sometimes lumps can hide within the batter (doesn't take away from the end product though)

text:
Well I did a slight variation, I did it with 1 1/4 cups flour, 3 eggs and 2/3 cup chicken broth. When I made them growing up in High School in Culinary Arts. I remember them being somewhat more, watery, for lack there of a better word, and having been more egg based  well. So this is my first adaptation after a while. But I am sure I will find something closer to what I remember, that just has the thickness and fluffiness that it truly should. I myself have always been partial to more savory these days and have always liked more savory crepes too. I usually tend to add about a tsp of Garlic powder, Marjoram, Tarragon and Dalmatian Sage, and I never use regular salt, prefer using celery salt for the flavor. A sea salt and celery seed grinder would be perfect..!! Pretty basic though, anybody can always tweek something to make it there own.. Don't be afraid to experiment :)!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made it in the blender. I needed a tad more liquid and more blending of the flour. I hadn't read reviews and haven't been cooking with dairy. I usually consider crepe #1 to be the test one. With the liquid, water, and flour better incorporated, the second one was better. I made half of the recipe in a very nice, nonstick crepe pan spayed with vegetable oil. I served with powdered sugar and blueberries. Were I to make them again, I'd make sure to blend the flour better, maybe sifting as suggested above, and experiment with two tbls rather than 1/4th cup for the first crepe. I almost made them at midnight to rest overnight and might do that. But, in any case, I'll let the batter rest, as suggested, for 20 min. I'll still use the blender for ease of making, pouring, and clean up. This recipe is the traditional one, and I'm glad it's readily available.

Display Name:
Tatyana Malyarenko Johnson

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1948205.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really like this recipe! It's just enough for 2 or 3 people (it makes about 5 to 6 crepes depending on the size of the pan). I made my personal modifications to this recipe. I use 1 cup of milk instead of half milk and half water, they turn out much tastier. I also reduced amount of flour a little (a little less than a cup), because my batter was thicker than I usually like for my crepes. I also added 1tsp of vanilla extract. The secret of making a good crepe is not to grease the pan too much, but just a little bit. Also, use non-stick pan so that crepes don't stick to the pan. I also changed the process of mixing it. I start with beaten egg, I add warm milk, melted butter, salt and vanilla extract and at the very end I gradually add the flour. It mixes a lot faster and easier than it's described in this recipe.

text:
I use this recipe simply for ease, but I would be open to trying a better one for two reasons:
1. I can't figure out why you would whisk the flour and eggs first. This makes a dough, which then becomes impossible lumps when you add the liquid.
2. I usually have to add more liquid (I kind of eyeball it) to get the consistency that's right for spreading the batter around the pan.

text:
This recipe was exactly what I was looking for: a basic, no frills recipe using ingredients I have on hand. The resulting crepes made a good base for both savory or sweet fillings. I docked a star because some changes to the original recipe were necessary: the batter came out rather thick so I added water until it thinned out to  proper crepe-batter consistency. Also, the mixing indtructions are a little odd so I went with the Tried & True mix wet, mix dry, then mix dry into wet.

text:
recipe ratios are spot on. the issue I had and I should have known better was adding melted butter to cold milk. it turned back into a solid before I could get it blended properly. for better results. the milk/water should be warmed up to around 45c and butter added. mix all dry ingredients whilst adding the eggs last to insure the temp is low enough to not cook the egg during mixing.

text:
Really easy to make with simple  ingredients. I use vegetable oil on the skillet and spread the oil using a folded paper towel - moderation is the key. When the oil get low I give the pan a minute or two to heat up again. If you're getting big bubbles in your crepe you are probably using too much oil and/or too high heat. Love them with strawberry jam and peanut butter, and so do my two year olds!

userID:
16055649
Display Name:
Cagineer
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I learnt how to make beautiful French crepes from a Frenchman who studied food preparation in France. Must use a well seasoned crepe pan. 

He places mixed dry ingredients in a mixing bowl, piled in the middle. Makes a well in the centre of the pile into which pours the pre mixed wet ingredients at room temperature (one egg per person, milk, salt, melted butter). He then stirs the wet ingredients in the centre keeping to small circles and gradually work his way into larger and larger circles as the liquids incorporate all the dry ingredients. It is important to work your way in larger circles slowly to ensure flour is well "wetted". When all blended it is frigerated for an hour. To cook: heat up the crepe pan over medium heat, making sure the pan is thoroughly heated and put butter on it, allow it to melt and coat the surface evenly. Slowly pour about 4-6 tbsp of batter (ketchup consistency)  onto the crepe pan and tilt the pan to encourage batter to flow and evenly coat the pan. Allow to cook over medium heat for a few minutes until surface looks dry. Peel crepe off pan, (if it doesn't peel off easily it is not ready. Flip. Repeat. Enjoy. Re butter pan for next crepe.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
My gas stove was way too hot, and it made the batter bubble, which left it with an uneven spongy/leathery texture. Crepes are supposed to be light and fluffy.  Better for it to take longer.  It also helps if you have better cookware.  If your pan does not heat evenly, you'll end up with brown spots or bubbles where the pan is hotter.

text:
I like this recipe, enough that I've made it twice to go with a strawberries and creme filling from a separate recipe. It tastes very delicious and when they come out well they are beautiful and of an excellent texture. However, I tend to have some trouble with the consistency. Make sure to mix the ingredients in the order it tells you or you'll have problems with it being too thick (I did that this time). I'm going to try a different recipe next time though because the consistency is just a little bit off even when done correctly. Hasn't failed me either time though although both times I wished I had doubled it, there was just enough for everyone to have two with one left over.

text:
This is a really nice recipe and one that you can literally decide to prepare on a whim.  I like to add a little sugar (vanilla sugar is even better - store sugar and a vanilla pod together in a jar until you're happy with the taste & aroma) to the batter for sweet crepes.  My favorite way to eat them goes back to "Pancake Day" growing up in England - lemon juice and brown sugar and then rolled up - delicious!  I still eat them like this, although a little Nutella is also yummy.

text:
Tried making crepes for the first time last night and used this recipe. I took the advice from another comment and mixed wet and dry ingredients separate and sifted in the dry. Worked lovely! My only complaint is I found the batter too thick. I added in at least another 1/2 cup of milk, (should have measured but didn't), and it was much better! Nice and thin! I realized the pan does have to be good and hot for the crepe to really turn out the best :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my first time at crepes, and it turned out surprisingly well. I did follow Morely's instructions about mixing all wets first (eggs, milk, water, butter) and then salt and 1/4 tsp vanilla before I sifted in the flour at the end and whisked it thoroughly. I used a lightly oiled cast iron pan over just above medium heat (gas stove) and used 1/4 cup measurements of batter and spread it out by rotating my pan and it worked out awesome. I cooked 2 minutes on one side and made sure it was loose from the pan by giving the pan a shake, flipped it and put a little fruit on top in the middle in a line, flipped the sides up and removed it from the pan. I then tossed a spoon of plain yogurt on and sprinkled with a little icing sugar. This is a stellar recipe :) Thank you

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I agree with the comment above that for even decent results you have to whisk the eggs and milk together first, then add the flour. Also every recipe should include the fact that the best results don't happen by adding an exact  measured amount of flour. it's best to add the flour a bit at a time until it coats the whisk more on the thin side for very thin "crepes" and a thicker coating for more substantial ones. PLUS, the most important omission is that it possibly originated in Czechoslovakia as Palacinky and is a mainstay of Viennese cuisine as Palatschenke.

text:
These are the best crepes I have ever made! My nephews and siblings are always asking for them! This is the only recipe I will ever need. Instead of mixing the flour and eggs then add the wet ingredients  I add all the wet ingredients then the dry. It makes smooth batter that way and is far better and easier.

userID:
9043918
Display Name:
Jenplus4fr

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have not yet tried this recipe, but since I live in France, I have more than enough experience with making crepes!  The way it is always mixed together here is to mix the dry ingredients together in a bowl, make a well in the center, then break open the eggs into the well.  Slowly pour the liquids in while gently whisking the eggs around - this mixes in the flour gradually and avoids most lumps.  Then add the melted butter.  THEN, the batter sits for about an hour.  This allows the rest of the lumps to reabsorb.  We often add a bit of rum or lemon juice/zest, also, for flavoring.  Enjoy!

text:
This is a very good basic recipe. But I had to remake it because it says to add the flour first which makes it clumpy. So add all the wet ingredients and then whisk in the flour little by little. I also added a little bit of sugar for sweetness. Also I had to adjust it to using 1/3 cup of batter for my pan size. Make sure you spread the batter out quickly!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just tried this recipe and it was quite delicious. I did increase the salt just a little bit, added some sugar, a bit of orange zest and a splash of vanilla. Very easy with great results. Just like many others on here, I would mix the wet and dry ingredients separately, adding the dry gradually to the wet so you don't get lumps and use a wire whisk. Will definitely make again. Also, I made these as a sweet breakfast entrée. For savory crepes, leave out the sweeteners

text:
I am thinking of ways to be creative with the basic crepe.  One thought is with a concoction of shrimp, cream cheese (maybe not cream cheese, but something with a good melt...Havarti?  Brie?), chives, Worcestershire sauce, dash of hot sauce.  Maybe drizzle a hollandaise on the plate?  I will absolutely HAVE to make a bunch so I can freeze some and try a couple different ideas.  Of course, old fashioned fresh sliced fruit and whipped cream kind is my favorite.  Just thought of another idea.  Roll them up and dip one end in a caramel sauce (that will hard set, roll the end in brown sugar (before it sets)and serve with ice cream.  By the way, liked the idea someone had to add vanilla extract.  Could try with orange too, nice and bright taste.

text:
This is a great base recipe and can be adapted in many ways. However, for easier prep and better consistency I add all the ingredients to a blender and blend until smooth. I let the batter sit for just a few minutes the pour straight into the pan. If I am using this recipe for a dessert crepe I omit the salt and add 1/2 tsp sugar to the batter instead. Enjoy!!

I loved this recipe I bought a crepe flat teflon pan today with wooden roller and your recipe is the first I tried. My daughter yesterday told me crepes were her favourite.... I doubled the recipe and used mixer to mix eggs milk and water added tablespoon of vanilla sugar the salt and some powdered sugar and vanilla extract and finished with the flour and they came out amazing(about two thirds a cup per crepe. I even used stoneground "70" whole wheat flour (so had to add some more milk for consistency). userID:
3065987
Display Name:
Mischelle40
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This batter is too thick to be crepe batter.  I had to add more liquid.   It should be thin enough that you can swirl your pan quickly to cover the bottom before it begins to set.  I also added a bit of sugar and a little vanilla because we prefer it that way.  Once you get it thin enough, this makes really good batter.  We lived in France for three years, and traditionally, they like it with cinnamon and sugar and melted butter, or filled with Nutella, or filled with bananas.  We prefer it filled with a mixture of cream cheese, powdered sugar, and vanilla and topped with homemade mixed berry topping.  My youngest likes it with the filling and drizzled with chocolate syrup.  To the person who said they could not see mixing the flower and eggs, you are right.  The best way to mix this batter is to put all the ingredients into the blender, pulse until everything is nicely mixed, and then let the batter rest in the fridge for 1/2 hour to 1 hour, to allow excess air from mixing to escape.  

Overall, the taste is really good if you get the batter thinner.  I would use this recipe again, with my modifications.

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely fantastic recipe. I would give it a 5 star for the ingredients and proportions but a 1 star for directions. 

Changes I made:
added about 1 tsp of vanilla and 2 tsp of sugar to make it more of a breakfast crepe. 

For combining I followed another reviewers recommendations and combined the wet ingredients (minus the melted butter)and whisked until combined
Then add the flour (which I spooned into the measuring cup so as not to make the batter to thick) and salt and whisk until no longer lumpy 
Finally add the melted butter and combine. 
This results in a lump free batter that is the perfect consistency for crepes!

text:
I initially followed the recipe minus the salt, I was making a kind of desert dish that you can put peanut butter and jelly and syrup all over. So I forewent the salt, the first batch turned out alright, though thick... So when I went to make the second batch I added a bit more milk and a touch of vanilla extract, and didn't add butter (mainly because I forgot...). 

The second batter turned out much better than the first and recipe given. That's why I  only gave three stars, mainly because my changes made the batter better :)

text:
This turned out awesome! I did exactly as it said, mixd flour and eggs. You have to fully mix till moistened. It was a bit lumpy but just keep mixing till slightly smooth. Then added other wet ingredients and when it became too much to mix by hand, used hand held mixer. Combined great and cooked evenly! I made dinner crepes with bacon, arugula, parm and a little spread of garlic cream cheese and avocados on top. Turned out AMAZING! Next time will try desert crepe.

text:
Made this for my roommate to welcome her back from reading week. It was perfect! The crepes had exactly the texture i wanted. I did what a lot of the comments advised to do, which was to mix all the what ingredients first and then add the flour. Made it so much easier.

Tip to get rid of lumps (i still had some in my batter): pour the batter through a strainer. It works great!

text:
This recipe turned out great! It reminded me of my dad's homemade waffle recipe which we only get to enjoy once a year. It helps that my dad is French and I've had authentic french crepes (some what similar to these except a little less doughy) to give me a better idea for what to expect. The only thing I did differently was that I added about 3 tablespoons of sugar and a half tablespoon of vanilla extract to make it have that full flavor I love. I will definitely be making these more often rather than going out and buying pre-mixed mix at the store.

I made this recipe as a first attempt at crepes. Was easy to make and tasted good although I did make some changes based on people’s comments. text:
Great recipe!! Just mix all the wet ingredients together, then add flour or you get a lumpy batter, some people suggest adding sugar, but i recommend you do not, as if you make it a dessert crepe, it will be too sweet if sugar is added. I make mine by spreading Nutella, graham cracker cookie(crumbled up) and sliced bananas, roll and add a dollop of whipped cream on top! Makes a great dessert, My kids love it!! Quick and easy!! Thanks!!

userID:
9278922
Display Name:
katiewinkler
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
721
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I like this recipe a lot! I added a cup of milk and no water though. And a tbsp. of raw sugar and some organic Almond extract which I'm not sure I tasted in the crepes.
 The best way not to have lumpy batter and easiest is to make it in the blender, then let the batter rest a few minutes, which I always do. I make cheese blintzes by sweetening some Aldi's ricotta cheese w/ a couple tbsp. of TJ organic powdered sugar.  After the crepe comes out of the pan I spoon and spread the ricotta across the middle of the crepe and roll it up. You can top it with some jam, I just used some TJ pumpkin butter! 
Our second crepe this morning was spread down the middle with 2tbsp. of Nutella and then bannana rounds down the whole center and rolled up w/ a little more Nutella spread on top. My husband said it would be pretty w/some of the powdered sugar sprinkled on top. He and my 20mo. son ate them both up quickly!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
A new staple in my kitchen. This is the best crepe recipe I have ever found. To avoid clumps, mix all of the wet ingredients first and beat well. Then slowly beat in the flour/salt two tablespoons at a time until thick and no clumps remain. I also added a teaspoon vanilla. Yummy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just finished making these crepes for me and my 2 year old son. They were absolutely delicious!! I did make slight variations, I added cinnamon, 2 Tbsp sugar, a tsp vanilla and a tiny bit of extra flour to thicken just a little. They came out great! I cooked them on a large round pan and they were so easy to flip taking not even five minutes per crepe. I did spray cooking spray after each crepe and never had a problem with sticking. As I took each crepe off of the pan I melted butter on each side and sprinkled a littlegranulated sugar on top. I had some peach preserves I had bought from the farmers market so I put some in a bowl and warmed them up for 30 seconds in the microwave, poured that on one crepe and put another crepe on top of that and the rest of the warm peach preserves on top. My son and I loved it!! These crepes were so easy to make and they made enough for a couple of meals, can't wait to make them again, might try them with nutella next time, I think they would taste even better that way!!

text:
It's a great basic recipe for crepes, it is simple and to the point and doesn't need to sit in the fridge.  I usually add a little something for flavor : vanilla extract, lime, orange zest, orange blossom water, rum, or anything that gives it a little twist. I usually mix the ingredients in the order given by the recipe to avoid lumps in the batter, and if needed use the blender but mildly.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This crepe batter is really, really good! I mixed the dry ingredients in my stand mixer with the whisk attachment, then poured in the milk, water, & 1/2 t. of vanilla all at once, mixed it well, and then added the eggs and mixed well again. It blended wonderfully and I only had a few tiny specks that didn't mix that were settled at the bottom of the bowl when I was done pouring & making them. I did take another reviewers advice on adding the vanilla and 1/3 c. of sugar, but it was a tiny bit too sweet after we put our strawberry filling inside and the sweetened whip cream on top. They were so good I decided to make more for the next day and some to freeze, so I made the recipe again, doubling it, and only used the 1/3 c. for both instead of each, and that was perfect for us. These were great! :) (I just wish they were faster to cook! lol)

text:
this was a great recipe - my mother was french and an excellent pastry chef. we grew up eating crepes for breakfast instead of pancakes. Thank you! this recipe is the closest i have ever come to duplicating her delicious crepes.
I have multiple allergies so I substituted the flour for gluten free (rice/tapioca based), the milk for so-delicious brand coconut milk (unsweetened vanilla in the carton) and the butter for earth balance brand organic coconut spread. Excellent results and even my husband could not taste the difference for the substitutions.

text:
I half-ed the recipe since I made it for one person. The first crepe came out a bit hard so I added a little more milk to thin it out. The second one came out perfectly :) . So if you halfen the recipe add a little more milk. Just enough to thin the mixture a bit. Maybe 1/8 cup of milk. And thanks to everyone's helpful comments I blended my wet ingredients before adding the flour :) ! Anyhoo, really really good. And if you're looking for a healthy vegan cream process 1cup of cashews with your favorite fruit and refrigerate for a bit. Can be eaten right out of the processor too but refrigeration will thicken it more. Add honey too if you'd like. Yaaaaay fooooood!

text:
WOW! I've never made crepes before and was always under the impression that they were difficult to make. Not this recipe! I did the wet ingredients first with the whisk in the mixer but realized my half batch wasn't big enough for my mixer so I whisked in the dry ingredients myself. I added some sugar and vanilla for sweet breakfast crepes. The batter was smooth and thin and they came out beautiful! They only needed less than a minute on the pan before they were ready for a flip. A little powdered sugar, whipped cream, and boysenberry jam and they were amazing! I can't wait to make more!

Awesome, simple recipe! I agree with Morley though, reverse the order and sift in the flour to avoid lumps.  I also added zero salt, and instead added a -load (technical cooking term) of sugar (to taste).  I serve them with fruit, walnuts, fudge, butterscotch, and whipped cream, so I want them sweet instead of salty.

text:
This recipe was pretty good.  I would suggest not mixing it in the order indicated as whisking 2 eggs and flour just gives you a large clump.  I would instead mix the flour and salt together and then add all the wet ingredients except for the butter. Once those were combined I would add in the butter. The recipe also makes a very small amount and my family finished them off in no time.  We usually use a better recipe from the site, that I have rated in the past, but I accidently brought this one up.

text:
This recipe works like a charm every time I try it.  My husband was very skeptical I could make these from scratch, especially as we don't have a crepe pan (and I'm not the world's greatest cook).  However, this recipe has never failed me, and I got the best compliment ever when I made them for a French friend and she asked for seconds!

Quick technical note, instead of a regular frying pan, I use a non-stick pan with no oil.  With the heat somewhere between low and medium (3.5 on our stove), the non-stick pan works perfectly for cooking the crepes.

text:
It was my first time making crepes. This was a good recipe. I tried it the way the instructions said, and for me it needed more flavor. I gradually added more ingredients so the flavor was to my liking. In the end this is what I added: 1 tsp vanilla, 2 TBSP powder sugar, and a dash of cinnamon. I like the end result. Next time I'll try to prep stuff to add to the crepes. I'll have to do that in advance because I was too hungry to wait.

Display Name:
flassoon

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, moist crêpes.  Will use again.  ** Do not follow mixing directions in recipe!** Mix liquids in one bowl, then added pre-mixed dry ingredients.  Added 1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/4 C sugar for sweet crêpes and about 1/2 C extra liquid (water and/or milk) until batter was runny.  When frying I only used butter on the first one; non-stick pans don't need it.  Served 3 ways: sprinkled with sugar and lemon juice, with maple syrup, and with chocolate-hazelnut spread (with optional coconut).  May try omitting sugar and vanilla next time and making savoury ones (with cheese, eggs, spinach, asparagus, tomatoes and/or ham inside).

text:
Lovely recipe. I added about 1/2 cup of milk and 1/2 cup of water to the recipe, bringing each to a full cup. It makes the batter thinner, making the crepes crisp a little more. Next time I would probably add an entire cup of each to thin it out even further.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried several crepe recipes and this one is the best one. They turned out like real french crepes you find in Paris. Even better with a little nutella spread on  :-)

Update: It seems the next few times I tried this, it wasn't cooperating as well. As per other comments, doing the flour and eggs together creates a big pasty mess that doesn't blend easily with the milk (you'll most likely end up with lumps). I put the liquids together first, then blend the dry in. Still good recipe as far as ingredients, but the instructions are odd.

To BABYGIRL30S, I usually butter a non-stick pan instead of using oil, because there is an oily texture to the outside of the crepes. I also loosen it with a spatula and then flip it like you would when you're tossing a pizza. Hope this helps!

Crepe success! I went ahead and prepared the batter as listed, without added sugar. This way, I had the option of making more savory crepes (with melted cheese or sour cream) or sweet crepes (the jam or yogurt added the desired sweetness). I was even able to do some air flips! text:
Super easy. 
Just mix the ingredients together like the recipe says for success! I used a metal skillet on 4/10 heat on my stove dial and cooked for a couple minutes on each side. At that heat it is easy to spread the batter around. If you make them thin and let them get crispy it is easier to roll and pick them up. Floppier ones are better to eat with a fork. This recipe made enough for about 5 crepes.

Display Name:
Elisabetta
