photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent crepes. I had no problems with the unsifted flour and eggs. I whisked the eggs with the flour, first. I then whisked the milk followed by the water. Then salt and melted butter. I cooked them on a griddle, medium heat and they were delicious. I used a 1/4 cup for each and just poured them starting in the middle and working my way out in a circle. That way, there is no need to swirl the pan or griddle around. They were perfect. Just before they are cooked, I put on eggs (filled w/bacon and gruyere' cheese), then put grated gruyere' on top, put another crepe on top and cook it just for a minute on each side. Yum! I also fill the crepes (after they've cooled). I first use Nutella (or hot fudge) to spread on the two crepes then pile coconut ice cream on top and sliced bananas on top of that. You can also add or substitute strawberries. Cover w/the 2nd crepe and slather whipped cream on the whole thing. DELISH!

text:
This really is a great basic recipe, not too egg-y which I prefer, due to the 1 cup of flour. (Some recipes call for 2 eggs with 1/2 cup flour.) One tip to insure your batter mixture is mixed well and makes it EASY...put all ingredients in the blender and pulse until mixed well.

I noticed my first few crepes would not spread out evenly in pan. Solution add a little more water in batter and wa-la, perfect crepes. I did melt butter in skillet each time before cooking.

I also added some icing sugar into the batter, then filled the cooked crepes with bananna slices and chocolate chips :) Amazing!!

text:
Yummy! Easy and delicious.  After reading other reviews, I combined the wet ingredients (plus about a tsp of vanilla) and the dry ingredients (plus about a  tsp of sugar), then combined them and whisked until smooth, and added the butter to that.  I filled with nutella and strawberries and they were great! Spread out the batter as soon as you pour it, because they cook quickly.

text:
great flavour, use this as my go-to crepe recipe every time-I find I have to run the whole mixture through a sieve to get rid of the lumps, and I usually add about 1/4 cup more milk so that the batter spreads around the pan more easily. Delicious! It tasted just like the crepes I have been craving since my trip to Paris, only less greasy. I added Nutella and raspberries for that additional WOW. Fold it in half, then thirds, and wrap in parchment paper for the authentic Parisian experience.   Thanks to Morley for the tip; it is imperative to mix the wet stuff before sifting in the dry or you'll be left with tons of unstirable lumps.

text:
I love crepes and these are awesome! For crepe filling, I mixed 8 oz of Neufchatel cheese with 4 tbsp of sugar and heated blueberries (microwaved frozen blueberries). Then topped with homemade whipped cream. Another filling we tried which was good (not as good as the Neufchatel cheese, but still good) was vanilla yogurt and fresh fruit, and topped with homemade whipped cream. Either way, the crepes were quite tasty! the only change I made was to use grapeseed oil instead of butter, and it seemed fine!

country:
None
text:
A good, simple crepe batter. I added 2 T Gran Marnier, 2 T sugar and replaced the milk & water with 1/4 c half and half and 2 c water. Blend all wet ingredients before slowly adding flour. For a quick Crepes Suzette, heat equal parts of orange marmalade and water in a pan until melted to syrup consistency. Add Brandy or Grand marnier and serve.

text:
It was a perfect recipe for perfect crepes.  it was my first attempt and they were beautiful and yummy.  Even my picky eater ate one.  I filled mine with 1 package of cream cheese, juice of one orange (lemon would taste nice too, but didn't have any), powdered sugar, a little milk (the cream cheese filling was cooked separately of course!).  then, i topped the crepes with blueberries that i cooked in water and splenda.  i thickened the blueberries with a little corn starch.  My husband devoured the crepes.  I can hardly wait to take this recipe to the beach with us this summer.  i tried to duplicated my favorite crepes from a breakfast restaurant that i frequent, but it was close enough.  enjoy!

text:
I made these today -- followed the instructions, even added the eggs to the flour and then thinned the resultant mass with the milk and water.    Because the batter was quite thin before I finished adding the liquid, I left out a scan 1/4 C of the liquid and it turned out great.  I am letting most of the batter rest in the fridge for a few hours and will add more liquid if it's too thick at that point.  Since I'm making sweet crepes, I also added about a tablespoon of sugar.  Delicious!

text:
the construction of this recipe is backwards. The best method, I've found, is to combine the liquids except for the melted butter. Next, add the flour to the mixture 1 part at a time with an electric mixer. Once the batter is smooth add the melted butter. Perfect every time for me.

text:
I love these crepes, and my friends and family love them! I add a bit of vanilla (probably about 3/4 of a tsp...I just eyeball it) and about probably 1/8 of a cup of powdered sugar. I found that when I found the directions and mixed the flour and eggs first, it was very lumpy, so I just dump everything into a bowl and use a wire whisk. There are still some lumps, but it's still delicious! I really recommend this recipe, it's fabulous!

Diana

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved it. My favorite filling in the world is a mix with small curd cottage cheese and raspberry jam (or whatever). SO good. jam is too sweet for me, and the cottage cheese calms it down. Then, i put a bit of heavy whipping cream in the bottom of a baking dish, put rolled crepes in there side by side and put some more cream on top of them and then stick them in 375 oven for 20-30  minutes (careful not to burn them. if they dry out, put a little more cream). Be careful if you do this because the cream 'calms down' the jam too and then it tastes too bland. So if you do this, make the filling sweeter than you like and then it should be fine. These crepes were awesome though! my first attempt!

After reading many reviews and seeing that everyone does something different with these crepes, I was inspired and just slightly confused! Lol..So i did my own thing too. I love vanilla extract, so i added 1 1/2 teas. of it along with about a quarter cup granulated sugar. I mixed wet ingredients with dry, against the advise of many reviewers and it still came out fine. I filled mine with cream cheese and sweetened strawberries then sprinkled with powdered sugar. They were absolutely fabulous!

Seriously, I only made these, like, a half-hour ago, and my Mom and picky little sister LOVED them!

I did as advised in other reviews- wet stuff first and then flour- and they turned out fine. I also let them sit in the fridge for about 10 minutes, and the coldness didn't effect them. Texture was fine, everything was fine, this recipe was great!

I, myself, as a young chef, just need to work on evening out the batter more and not letting the crêpes brown as much. I topped mine with strawberries and whipped cream and they were fantastic.

Thanks for your recipe; I can shape it up for myself now!

Double the recipe!!!!!
The first time I used this recipe, I was disappointed by how little it yielded! I had to go back and make a second set immediately because people were hungry! This is not enough for even a couple. So my advice? Double the recipe, and just blend all the ingredients together :-)

text:
My mom made these for a bridal show and it was AWESOME! I'm fifteen and it's really easy to make, I even fried it or whatever you call it! Just mix the ingrediants exactly like it tells you and add a tablespoon of sugar to sweeten it like one of the reviews said. Everyone brought stuff to top the crepes with like whipped cream, cocktail fruits from the cans, cinnamon, and syrup. 

One of the ladies there was from South Africa and she told us they ate crepes there by sprinkling sugar and cinnamon on them. She said they put them on top of each other to steam in a pot so it turns into a kind of syrup and drizzle lemon juice on. I never tried it but it sounds delicious.

This is the exact recipe in my Salton crepe maker booklet. I have found that mixing it in the blender eliminates lumps. When doubling the recipe, I don't double the butter, or it is so greasy the batter won't adhere to my crepe maker, for some reason

Great recipe.  I did add 1/4 tsp sugar, used 1/3 cup per crepe and generated 9 crepes.  Followed others and mixed milk, water, vanilla together before mixing alternately into egg batter with flour. Definately a hit!

text:
This recipe was fabulous. It was so easy and turned out really moist. For filling, I used 3 peeled and sliced peaches, 1/4 C butter and 1/4 C brown sugar. I cooked over medium heat until peaches were tender and sauce had thickened. After the sauce cooled slightly and thickened even more, I filled 4 crepes, added a dollup of fresh whipped cream on top and dusted with a little powdered sugar. It was sooooooo easy and tasted absolutely amazing!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1016676.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe.  I had leftover scrambled eggs and got the idea from a restaurant commercial (happens to be one of my husband's favorite non-pancake breakfasts).  I followed the crepe recipe exactly, and meanwhile cooked some chopped bacon and deli smoked turkey together (its what I had), set that to drain and used the grease for a roux based cheese sauce (milk, velveeta and cheddar - again - what I had).  I then nuked my eggs and folded in the meat and enough cheese to our liking.  I spooned this mix down the middle of these incredible (and unlike other recipes - sturdy) crepes, covered w/grated cheese and nuked just to start the cheese melting.  My husband says they're better than restaurant. I love them - seems complex, but was surprisingly fast and easy.  This is the only crepe recipe I would use. Others are too delicate or too gummy.

text:
Excellent, easy recipe. I used a good pan and had no trouble with sticking, flipping was easy. Once you let the batter set, just before flipping, I like to shake the pan hard to loosen the crepe, that makes it easier to flip. I served these with a savory filling with success, but I think I would like to have them next time with fruit and powdered sugar!!

text:
these came out sooooo good! i added nutmeg, cinnamon, and vanilla as suggested by a previous reviewer and the flavor was wonderful. i was worried because i was sure i would mess up, but these were so easy to make and came out just wonderful. i filled with strawberries and sprinkled powdered sugar on top. made these as part of brunch for mother's day and my mom gobbled them up! thanks!

Very good basic recipe!  I use all the same ingredients, but I add 1 TBSP of sugar to my batter.  Otherwise, they taste a little bland to me.
